abate.definition: (noun) Abatement.; (verb) (obsolete outside law) To put an end to; to cause to cease.

aberrant.definition: (noun) A person or object that deviates from the rest of a group.; (adjective) Differing from the norm.

abet.definition: (noun) Fraud or cunning.; (verb) To urge on, stimulate (a person to do) something desirable.

abeyance.definition: (noun) Expectancy; condition of ownership of real property being undetermined; lapse in succession of ownership of estate, or title.
abeyance.examples: (noun) The proceeds of the estate shall be held in abeyance in an escrow account until the minor reaches age twenty-one.

abhor.definition: (verb) To regard with horror or detestation; to shrink back with shuddering from; to feel excessive repugnance toward; to detest to extremity; to loathe.
abhor.examples: (verb) I absolutely abhor being stuck in traffic jams

abide.definition: (verb) To endure without yielding; to withstand; await defiantly; to encounter; to persevere.
abide.examples: (verb) The old oak tree abides the wind endlessly.

abject.definition: (noun) A person in the lowest and most despicable condition; a castaway; outcast.; (adjective) Sunk to or existing in a low condition, state, or position.

abjure.definition: (verb) To renounce upon oath; to forswear; to disavow.
abjure.examples: (verb) To abjure allegiance to a prince.

abound.examples: (verb) Wild animals abound wherever man does not stake his claim.

abreast.definition: (adjective) Side by side, facing forward.; (adverb) Side by side and facing forward.; (preposition) Abreast of; alongside.
abreast.examples: (adjective) to keep abreast of [or with] the present state of science.; (adverb) She believes it is important to keep abreast of new scientific developments.; (preposition) This ship sank abreast the island.

abrogate.definition: (verb) To annul by an authoritative act; to abolish by the authority of the maker or her or his successor; to repeal; — applied to the repeal of laws, decrees, ordinances, the abolition of customs, etc.; (adjective) Abrogated; abolished.

abscond.definition: (verb) To flee, often secretly; to steal away, particularly to avoid arrest or prosecution.
abscond.examples: (verb) The thieves absconded with our property.

abstain.examples: (verb) In order to improve his health, Rob decided to abstain from smoking.

abstract.definition: (noun) An abridgement or summary of a longer publication.; (verb) To separate; to disengage.; (adjective) Derived; extracted.
abstract.examples: (verb) He was wholly abstracted by other objects.

accentuate.definition: (verb) To pronounce with an accent or vocal stress.

acolyte.definition: (noun) One who has received the highest of the four minor orders in the Catholic Church, being ordained to carry the wine, water and lights at Mass.

acquiesce.definition: (verb) (with in (or sometimes with, to)) To rest satisfied, or apparently satisfied, or to rest without opposition and discontent (usually implying previous opposition or discontent); to accept or consent by silence or by omitting to object.

acrimonious.definition: (adjective) Harsh and sharp, or bitter and not pleasant to the taste; acrid, pungent.

acumen.definition: (noun) Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination.

adept.definition: (noun) One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient; (adjective) Well skilled; completely versed; thoroughly proficient

admonish.definition: (verb) To warn or notify of a fault; to reprove gently or kindly, but seriously; to exhort.

adulterate.definition: (verb) To corrupt.; (adjective) Tending to commit adultery.
adulterate.examples: (verb) to adulterate food, drink, drugs, coins, etc.

adverse.definition: (adjective) Unfavorable; antagonistic in purpose or effect; hostile; actively opposing one's interests or wishes; contrary to one's welfare; acting against; working in an opposing direction.

advocate.definition: (noun) Someone whose job is to speak for someone's case in a court of law; a counsel.; (verb) To plead in favour of; to defend by argument, before a tribunal or the public; to support, vindicate, or recommend publicly.
advocate.examples: (noun) Since she started working with her advocate, she has become much more confident.; (verb) I like trees, but I do not advocate living in them.

aesthetic.definition: (noun) The study of art or beauty.; (adjective) Concerned with beauty, artistic impact, or appearance.
aesthetic.examples: (noun) Her most recent works have this quirky, half-serious 90's teen culture-inspired aesthetic.; (adjective) It works well enough, but the shabby exterior offends his aesthetic sensibilities.

affectation.definition: (noun) An attempt to assume or exhibit what is not natural or real; false display; artificial show.

affinity.definition: (noun) A natural attraction or feeling of kinship to a person or thing.

affront.definition: (noun) An open or intentional offense, slight, or insult.; (verb) To insult intentionally, especially openly.
affront.examples: (noun) Such behavior is an affront to society.; (verb) to affront death

aggrandize.definition: (verb) To make great; to enlarge; to increase.

aghast.definition: (adjective) Terrified; struck with amazement; showing signs of terror or horror.
aghast.examples: (adjective) I was aghast when the incident unfolded in front of me.

agitate.definition: (verb) To disturb or excite; to perturb or stir up (a person).
agitate.examples: (verb) He was greatly agitated by the news.

alienate.definition: (noun) A stranger; an alien.; (verb) To convey or transfer to another, as title, property, or right; to part voluntarily with ownership of.; (adjective) (followed by "from") Estranged; withdrawn in affection; foreign

alleviate.definition: (verb) To make less severe, as a pain or difficulty.
alleviate.examples: (verb) Alcohol is often a cheap tool to alleviate the stress of a hard day.

allusive.definition: (adjective) That contains or makes use of allusions (indirect references or hints)

aloof.definition: (adjective) Reserved and remote; either physically or emotionally distant; standoffish.; (adverb) At or from a distance, but within view, or at a small distance; apart; away.; (preposition) Away from; clear of.

altruistic.examples: (adjective) His helping the old woman with her shopping was deemed highly altruistic by everyone, especially since her home was a mile away.

amalgamate.definition: (verb) To merge, to combine, to blend, to join.; (adjective) Coalesced; united; combined.
amalgamate.examples: (verb) to amalgamate one race with another

ambivalent.definition: (adjective) Simultaneously experiencing or expressing opposing or contradictory feelings, beliefs, or motivations.
ambivalent.examples: (adjective) He has an ambivalent relationship towards his parents.

ameliorate.definition: (verb) To make better, or improve, something perceived to be in a negative condition.
ameliorate.examples: (verb) They offered some compromises in an effort to ameliorate the situation.

amenable.definition: (adjective) Willing to respond to persuasion or suggestions.

amend.definition: (noun) (usually in the plural) An act of righting a wrong; compensation.; (verb) To make better; improve.

amicable.examples: (adjective) He was an amicable fellow with an easy smile.

amorphous.definition: (adjective) Lacking a definite form or clear shape.
amorphous.examples: (adjective) The enormous pile of spaghetti landed on the floor in an amorphous heap.

anachronistic.definition: (adjective) Erroneous in date; containing an anachronism; in a wrong time; not applicable to or not appropriate for the time.
anachronistic.examples: (adjective) If you know where to look in the movie, you can spot an anachronistic wrist watch on one of the Roman soldiers.

analogous.definition: (adjective) Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing some resemblance or proportion (often followed by "to".)

animosity.definition: (noun) Violent hatred leading to active opposition; active enmity; energetic dislike.

animus.definition: (noun) The basic impulses and instincts which govern one's actions.

anoint.definition: (verb) To smear or rub over with oil or an unctuous substance; also, to spread over, as oil.

anomalous.definition: (adjective) Deviating from the normal; marked by incongruity or contradiction; aberrant or abnormal.

antagonize.definition: (verb) To work against; to oppose (especially to incite reaction)
antagonize.examples: (verb) The other children constantly antagonized Joe to the point of tears.

antedate.definition: (noun) Prior date; a date antecedent to another which is the actual date.; (verb) To occur before an event or time; to exist further back in time.

antipathy.definition: (noun) A feeling of dislike (normally towards someone, less often towards something); repugnance or distaste.

antithesis.definition: (noun) A proposition that is the diametric opposite of some other proposition.

apathy.definition: (noun) Lack of emotion or motivation; lack of interest or enthusiasm towards something; disinterest (in something).

apogee.definition: (noun) The point, in an orbit about the Earth, that is furthest from the Earth: the apoapsis of an Earth orbiter.

appease.definition: (verb) To make quiet; to calm; to reduce to a state of peace; to dispel (anger or hatred).
appease.examples: (verb) to appease the tumult of the ocean

apprehension.definition: (noun) The physical act of seizing or taking hold of (something); seizing.

apprise.definition: (verb) To notify, or to make aware; to inform.

approbation.definition: (noun) The act of approving; an assenting to the propriety of a thing with some degree of pleasure or satisfaction; approval, sanction, commendation or official recognition.

appropriate.definition: (verb) To make suitable; to suit.; (adjective) Suitable or fit; proper.
appropriate.examples: (verb) Let no man appropriate the use of a common benefit.; (adjective) The headmaster wondered what an appropriate measure would be to make the pupil behave better.

apropos.definition: (adjective) Of an appropriate or pertinent nature.; (adverb) By the way.; (preposition) Regarding or concerning.

apt.definition: (adjective) Suitable; appropriate; fit or fitted; suited.

arbitrary.definition: (noun) Anything arbitrary, such as an arithmetical value or a fee.; (adjective) (usually of a decision) Based on individual discretion or judgment; not based on any objective distinction, perhaps even made at random.
arbitrary.examples: (adjective) Benjamin Franklin's designation of "positive" and "negative" to different charges was arbitrary.

archaic.definition: (noun) (usually capitalized) A general term for the prehistoric period intermediate between the earliest period (‘Paleo-Indian’, ‘Paleo-American’, ‘American‐paleolithic’, &c.) of human presence in the Western Hemisphere, and the most recent prehistoric period (‘Woodland’, etc.).; (adjective) Of or characterized by antiquity; old-fashioned, quaint, antiquated.

archetype.definition: (noun) An original model of which all other similar concepts, objects, or persons are merely copied, derivative, emulated, or patterned; a prototype.; (verb) To depict as, model using, or otherwise associate an object or subject with an archetype.

arduous.definition: (adjective) Needing or using up much energy; testing powers of endurance.
arduous.examples: (adjective) The movement towards a peaceful settlement has been a long and arduous political struggle.

arresting.definition: (verb) To stop the motion of (a person or animal).; (adjective) Striking, gripping
arresting.examples: (verb) The police have arrested a suspect in the murder inquiry.

articulate.definition: (noun) An animal of the subkingdom Articulata.; (adjective) Clear; effective.
articulate.examples: (adjective) She’s a bright, articulate young woman.

artless.definition: (adjective) Having or displaying no guile, cunning, or deceit.

ascertain.definition: (verb) To find out definitely; to discover or establish.
ascertain.examples: (verb) As soon as we ascertain what the situation is, we can plan how to proceed.

ascetic.definition: (noun) One who is devoted to the practice of self-denial, either through seclusion or stringent abstinence.; (adjective) Of or relating to ascetics

ascribe.definition: (verb) To attribute a cause or characteristic to someone or something.
ascribe.examples: (verb) One may ascribe these problems to the federal government; however, at this stage it is unclear what caused them.

aspersion.definition: (noun) An attack on somebody's reputation or good name, often in the phrase to cast aspersions upon….

assail.definition: (verb) To attack with harsh words or violent force (also figuratively).
assail.examples: (verb) Muggers assailed them as they entered an alley.

assertive.definition: (adjective) Boldly self-assured; confident without being aggressive.

assuage.definition: (verb) To lessen the intensity of, to mitigate or relieve (hunger, emotion, pain etc.).

astringent.definition: (noun) A substance which draws tissue together, thus restricting the flow of blood.; (adjective) Extremely sour, bitter.

attenuate.definition: (verb) To reduce in size, force, value, amount, or degree.; (adjective) (of leaves) Gradually tapering into a petiole-like extension toward the base.

audacious.definition: (adjective) Showing willingness to take bold risks; recklessly daring.

augment.definition: (noun) (grammar) In some Indo-European languages, a prefix e- (a- in Sanskrit) indicating a past tense of a verb.; (verb) To increase; to make larger or supplement.
augment.examples: (verb) The money from renting out a spare room can augment a salary.

august.examples: (adjective) an august patron of the arts

auspicious.definition: (adjective) Of good omen; indicating future success.

austere.definition: (adjective) Grim or severe in manner or appearance
austere.examples: (adjective) The headmistress was an austere old woman.

auxiliary.definition: (noun) A person or group that acts in an auxiliary manner.; (adjective) Helping; giving assistance or support.

avaricious.definition: (adjective) Actuated by avarice; extremely greedy for wealth or material gain; immoderately desirous of accumulating property.

aver.definition: (verb) To assert the truth of, to affirm with confidence; to declare in a positive manner.

aversion.definition: (noun) Opposition or repugnance of mind; fixed dislike.
aversion.examples: (noun) Due to her aversion to the outdoors she complained throughout the entire camping trip.

banal.definition: (adjective) Common in a boring way, to the point of being predictable; containing nothing new or fresh.

banish.definition: (verb) (heading) To send someone away and forbid that person from returning.

baroque.definition: (adjective) Ornate, intricate, decorated, laden with detail.

barrage.definition: (noun) An artificial obstruction, such as a dam, in a river designed to increase its depth or to divert its flow.; (verb) To direct a barrage at.

barren.definition: (noun) An area of low fertility and habitation, a desolate place.; (adjective) Unable to bear children; sterile.
barren.examples: (noun) The pine barrens are a site lonely enough to suit any hermit.; (adjective) I silently wept as my daughter's husband rejected her. What would she do now that she was no longer a maiden but also barren?

base.definition: (noun) Something from which other things extend; a foundation.; (verb) To give as its foundation or starting point; to lay the foundation of.; (noun) A low spectrum of sound tones.; (noun) A root.
base.examples: (noun) The logarithm to base 2 of 8 is 3.; (noun) Peter adjusted the equalizer on his audio equipment to emphasize the bass.

befuddled.definition: (verb) To perplex, confuse (someone).; (adjective) Confused or perplexed
befuddled.examples: (verb) The explanation left him completely befuddled.

beguile.examples: (verb) I will never touch The Orb, even though its mysterious glow seduces and beguiles.

belligerent.definition: (noun) A state or other armed participant in warfare; (adjective) Engaged in warfare, warring.
belligerent.examples: (noun) The UN sent a treaty proposal to the belligerents.

beneficent.definition: (adjective) Given to acts that are kind, charitable, philanthropic or beneficial.

benevolent.definition: (adjective) Having a disposition to do good.
benevolent.examples: (adjective) Chinese and Eastern mythologies describe dragons as benevolent.

berate.examples: (verb) What society tells people, that they could "do whatever they want" to dissidents, and yet berates anyone for treating them well?

bereft.definition: (verb) To deprive by or as if by violence; to rob; to strip; to benim.; (adjective) (of a person) Pained by the loss of someone.
bereft.examples: (verb) Death bereaved him of his wife.

betray.definition: (verb) To deliver into the hands of an enemy by treachery or fraud, in violation of trust; to give up treacherously or faithlessly.
related_words: pull the wool over someone's eyes

blithe.examples: (adjective) She had a blithe disregard of cultures outside the United States.

bogus.definition: (noun) A liquor made of rum and molasses.; (adjective) Counterfeit or fake; not genuine.

bolster.definition: (noun) A large cushion or pillow.; (verb) To brace, reinforce, secure, or support.

bombastic.definition: (adjective) (of a person, their language or writing) showy in speech and given to using flowery or elaborate terms; grandiloquent; pompous

boon.examples: (noun) Anaesthetics are a great boon to modern surgery.

boorish.definition: (adjective) Behaving as a boor; rough in manners.

bravado.definition: (noun) A swaggering show of defiance or courage.; (verb) To swagger; to brag.
bravado.examples: (noun) The angry customer stood in the middle of the showroom and voiced his complaints with loud bravado.

brazen.definition: (verb) To turn a brass color.; (adjective) Pertaining to, made of, or resembling brass (in color or strength).
brazen.examples: (adjective) She was brazen enough to deny stealing the handbag even though she was caught on closed-circuit television doing so.

bridle.definition: (noun) The headgear with which a horse is directed and which carries a bit and reins.; (verb) To put a bridle on.

brook.definition: (verb) To use; enjoy; have the full employment of.
brook.examples: (verb) I will not brook any disobedience.   I will brook no refusal.   I will brook no impertinence.

burgeon.definition: (noun) A bud, sprout, shoot.; (verb) To grow or expand.
burgeon.examples: (verb) Gradually, the town burgeoned into a thriving city.

burnish.definition: (noun) Polish; lustre.; (verb) To make smooth or shiny by rubbing; to polish; to shine.
burnish.examples: (verb) In pottery, a stone is sometimes used to burnish a pot before firing, giving it a smooth, shiny look.

buttress.definition: (noun) A brick or stone structure built against another structure to support it.; (verb) To support something physically with, or as if with, a prop or buttress.

byzantine.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to Byzantium.; (noun) A byzant (coin).

cacophonous.definition: (adjective) Containing, consisting of, or producing harsh, unpleasant or discordant sounds.

cajole.definition: (verb) To persuade someone to do something which they are reluctant to do, especially by flattery or promises; to coax.

callous.definition: (adjective) Emotionally hardened; unfeeling and indifferent to the suffering/feelings of others.; (noun) A hardened area of the skin (especially on the foot or hand) caused by repeated friction, wear or use.
callous.examples: (adjective) She was so callous that she could criticise a cancer patient for wearing a wig.

callow.definition: (noun) A callow young bird.; (adjective) Unfledged (of a young bird).
callow.examples: (adjective) Those three young men are particularly callow youths.

calumny.definition: (noun) A false accusation or charge brought to tarnish another's reputation or standing.; (verb) To make false accusations or levy false charges against a person with the intent to tarnish that person's reputation or standing; to calumniate.
calumny.examples: (noun) Accusations of abuse were pure extortive calumny in a malicious bid to make money.

candid.definition: (noun) A spontaneous or unposed photograph.; (adjective) Impartial and free from prejudice.
candid.examples: (noun) His portraits looked stiff and formal but his candids showed life being lived.

canny.definition: (adjective) Careful, prudent, cautious.; (adverb) Very, considerably; quite, rather.
canny.examples: (adjective) The politician gave a canny response to the reporter's questions.; (adverb) That's a canny big horse, man!

canonize.definition: (verb) To declare (a deceased person) as a saint, and enter them into the canon of saints.

capitulate.definition: (verb) To surrender; to end all resistance, to give up; to go along with or comply.
capitulate.examples: (verb) He argued and hollered for so long that I finally capitulated just to make him stop.

capricious.definition: (adjective) Impulsive and unpredictable; determined by chance, impulse, or whim
capricious.examples: (adjective) I almost died in a capricious winter storm.

captious.definition: (adjective) That captures; especially, (of an argument, words etc.) designed to capture or entrap in misleading arguments; sophistical.

caricature.definition: (noun) A pictorial representation of someone in which distinguishing features are exaggerated for comic effect.; (verb) To represent someone in an exaggerated or distorted manner.

castigate.definition: (verb) To punish or reprimand someone severely.

cataclysmic.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to a cataclysm; causing great destruction or upheaval; catastrophic.
cataclysmic.examples: (adjective) It is believed that a cataclysmic impact caused the extinction of the dinosaurs.

cathartic.definition: (noun) A laxative.; (adjective) Purgative; inducing (mental or physical) catharsis

caustic.definition: (noun) Any substance or means which, applied to animal or other organic tissue, burns, corrodes, or destroys it by chemical action; an escharotic.; (adjective) Capable of burning, corroding or destroying organic tissue.

cavalier.definition: (noun) A military man serving on horse, early modern cavalry officers who had abandoned the heavy armor of medieval knights.; (verb) Of a man: to act in a gallant and dashing manner toward (women).; (adjective) Not caring enough about something important.

cease.definition: (noun) Cessation; extinction (see without cease).; (verb) To stop.
cease.examples: (verb) And with that, his twitching ceased.

censure.definition: (noun) The act of blaming, criticizing, or condemning as wrong; reprehension.; (verb) To criticize harshly.

cerebral.definition: (adjective) Of, or relating to the brain, cerebrum, or cerebral cortex.

chagrin.definition: (noun) Distress of mind caused by a failure of aims or plans, want of appreciation, mistakes etc; vexation or mortification.; (verb) To bother or vex; to mortify.; (adjective) Feeling chagrin; annoyed; vexed, fretful.

chary.definition: (adverb) In a chary manner.; (adjective) Careful, cautious, shy, wary.

chastise.definition: (verb) To punish (someone), especially by corporal punishment.

chauvinistic.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to chauvinism or chauvinists.

cherish.definition: (verb) To treat with affection, care, and tenderness; to nurture or protect with care.

chicanery.definition: (noun) Deception by use of trickery, quibbling, or subterfuge.

chivalrous.definition: (adjective) (of a man) Honourable, especially to women; gallant.

churlish.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to a serf, peasant, or rustic.

circumscribe.definition: (verb) To draw a line around; to encircle.

circumspect.definition: (adjective) Carefully aware of all circumstances; considerate of all that is pertinent.
circumspect.examples: (adjective) Being aware of the danger of upsetting her audience, she was somewhat circumspect in her comments.

clandestine.definition: (adjective) Done or kept in secret, sometimes to conceal an illicit or improper purpose.

clangor.definition: (noun) A loud, repeating clanging sound; a loud racket; a din.; (verb) To make a clanging sound.

cloak.definition: (noun) A long outer garment worn over the shoulders covering the back; a cape, often with a hood.; (verb) To cover as with a cloak.
cloak.examples: (noun) Night hid her movements with its cloak of darkness.; (verb) The ship cloaked before entering the enemy sector of space.

coalesce.definition: (verb) (of separate elements) To join into a single mass or whole.
coalesce.examples: (verb) The droplets coalesced into a puddle.

coddle.definition: (noun) An Irish dish comprising layers of roughly sliced pork sausages and bacon rashers with sliced potatoes and onions.; (verb) To treat gently or with great care.

coercion.definition: (noun) (not countable) Actual or threatened force for the purpose of compelling action by another person; the act of coercing.

cogent.definition: (adjective) Reasonable and convincing; based on evidence.
cogent.examples: (adjective) The prosecution presented a cogent argument, convincing the jury of the defendant's guilt.

cogitate.definition: (verb) To meditate, to ponder, to think deeply.

coin.definition: (noun) (money) A piece of currency, usually metallic and in the shape of a disc, but sometimes polygonal, or with a hole in the middle.; (verb) To make of a definite fineness, and convert into coins, as a mass of metal.
coin.examples: (noun) She spent some serious coin on that car!; (verb) to coin a medal

collaborate.definition: (verb) To work together with others to achieve a common goal.
collaborate.examples: (verb) Let's collaborate on this project, and get it finished faster.

collude.definition: (verb) To act in concert with; to conspire

comity.definition: (noun) Courtesy and considerate behaviour towards others; social harmony.

commensurate.definition: (verb) To reduce to a common measure.; (adjective) Of a proportionate or similar measurable standard.

compelling.definition: (verb) To drive together, round up; (noun) An act of compulsion; an obliging somebody to do something.; (adjective) Strongly or irresistibly evoking interest or attention.
compelling.examples: (verb) Logic compels the wise, while fools feel compelled by emotions.; (adjective) There are compelling reasons why a manager should have previous experience.

competent.definition: (adjective) Having sufficient skill, knowledge, ability, or qualifications.
competent.examples: (adjective) He is a competent skier and an expert snowboarder.

complacent.definition: (adjective) Uncritically satisfied with oneself or one's achievements; smug.

complementary.definition: (noun) A complementary colour.; (adjective) Acting as a complement; making up a whole with something else.

comply.definition: (verb) To yield assent; to accord; to acquiesce, agree, consent; to adapt oneself, to conform.

compromise.definition: (noun) The settlement of differences by arbitration or by consent reached by mutual concessions.; (verb) To bind by mutual agreement.
compromise.examples: (noun) a compromise of character or right; (verb) He tried to compromise the security in the computer by guessing the password.

conciliatory.definition: (adjective) Willing to conciliate, or to make concessions.

condone.definition: (verb) To forgive, excuse or overlook (something that is considered morally wrong, offensive, or generally disliked).

conducive.definition: (adjective) Tending to contribute to, encourage, or bring about some result.
conducive.examples: (adjective) A small, dark kitchen is not conducive to elaborate cooking.

conflagration.definition: (noun) A large fire extending to many objects, or over a large space; a general burning.
conflagration.examples: (noun) It took sixty firefighters to put out the conflagration.

confound.definition: (noun) A confounding variable.; (verb) To perplex or puzzle.
confound.examples: (verb) Don't confound the situation by yelling.

congenial.definition: (adjective) Having the same or very similar nature, personality, tastes, habits or interests.
congenial.examples: (adjective) The congenial bartender makes the Hog’s Head an inviting place to hang out during the weekends.

conjectural.definition: (noun) Something that is conjectural; a conjecture.; (adjective) In the nature of a conjecture, or based on a conjecture.

connoisseur.definition: (noun) A specialist in a given field whose opinion is highly valued, especially in one of the fine arts or in matters of taste

consensus.definition: (noun) A process of decision-making that seeks widespread agreement among group members.
consensus.examples: (noun) After years of debate over the best wine to serve at Thanksgiving, no real consensus has emerged.

conspicuous.examples: (adjective) He was conspicuous by his absence.

conspire.definition: (verb) To secretly plot or make plans together, often with the intention to bring bad or illegal results.

construe.definition: (noun) A translation.; (verb) To interpret or explain the meaning of something.
construe.examples: (verb) The world must construe according to its wits; this court must construe according to the law.

contempt.definition: (noun) The state or act of contemning; the feeling or attitude of regarding someone or something as inferior, base, or worthless; scorn, disdain.

contend.definition: (verb) To strive in opposition; to contest; to dispute; to vie; to quarrel; to fight.
contend.examples: (verb) In this paper the author contends that no useful results can be obtained if this method is used.

contentious.definition: (adjective) Marked by heated arguments or controversy.

contravene.definition: (verb) To act contrary to an order; to fail to conform to a regulation or obligation.

contretemps.definition: (noun) An unforeseen, inopportune, or embarrassing event; a hitch

contrite.definition: (noun) A contrite person; a penitent.; (adjective) Sincerely penitent or feeling regret or sorrow, especially for one’s own actions; apologetic.

convalescent.definition: (noun) A person recovering from illness.; (adjective) Recovering one's health and strength after a period of illness
convalescent.examples: (noun) I had been ill in health, but am now a convalescent.; (adjective) She stayed in a convalescent hospital for two weeks before returning home.

conventional.definition: (noun) A conventional gilt-edged security, a kind of bond paying the holder a fixed cash payment (or coupon) every six months until maturity, at which point the holder receives the final payment and the return of the principal.; (adjective) Pertaining to a convention, as in following generally accepted principles, methods and behaviour.
conventional.examples: (adjective) They wear conventional clothes, eat conventional food, and keep conventional hours.

convivial.definition: (adjective) Having elements of a feast or of entertainment, especially when it comes to eating and drinking, with accompanying festivity

convoluted.definition: (verb) To make unnecessarily complex.; (adjective) Having numerous overlapping coils or folds; convolute.
convoluted.examples: (adjective) He gave a convoluted explanation that amounted to little more than a weak excuse for his absence.

copious.definition: (adjective) Vast in quantity or number, profuse, abundant; taking place on a large scale.

cordial.definition: (noun) A concentrated noncarbonated soft drink which is diluted with water before drinking.; (adjective) Hearty; sincere; warm; affectionate.

correlate.definition: (noun) Either of a pair of things related by a correlation; a correlative.; (verb) To compare things and bring them into a relation having corresponding characteristics

corroborate.definition: (verb) To confirm or support something with additional evidence; to attest or vouch for.

cosmopolitan.definition: (noun) A cosmopolitan person; a cosmopolite.; (adjective) Inclusive; affecting the whole world.

countenance.definition: (noun) Appearance, especially the features and expression of the face.; (verb) To tolerate, support, sanction, patronise or approve of something.
countenance.examples: (verb) The cruel punishment was countenanced by the government, although it was not officially legal.

covert.definition: (noun) A covering.; (adjective) Hidden, covered over; overgrown, sheltered.

covet.definition: (verb) To wish for with eagerness; to desire possession of, often enviously.

coy.definition: (verb) To caress, pet; to coax, entice.; (adjective) Bashful, shy, retiring.

craven.definition: (noun) A coward.; (verb) To make craven.; (adjective) Unwilling to fight; lacking even the rudiments of courage; extremely cowardly.

crescendo.definition: (noun) An instruction to play gradually more loudly, denoted by a long, narrow angle with its apex on the left ( < ), by musicians called a hairpin.; (verb) To increase in intensity; to reach or head for a crescendo.; (adverb) Gradually increasing in force or loudness.
crescendo.examples: (noun) Their fighting rose in a fearsome crescendo.; (verb) The band crescendoed and then suddenly went silent.

crestfallen.definition: (adjective) Sad because of a recent disappointment.

croon.definition: (noun) A soft or sentimental hum or song.; (verb) To hum or sing softly or in a sentimental manner.

cumbersome.definition: (adjective) Burdensome or hindering, as a weight or drag; vexatious
cumbersome.examples: (adjective) Cumbersome machines can endanger operators and slow down production.

cunning.definition: (adjective) Sly; crafty; clever in surreptitious behaviour.

curb.definition: (noun) A concrete margin along the edge of a road; a kerb (UK, Australia, New Zealand); (verb) To check, restrain or control.

curmudgeon.examples: (noun) John Doe's old age and stubborn aversion to new ideas make him a curmudgeon of a candidate.

cursory.examples: (adjective) Most junk mail requires only a cursory glance.

curtail.definition: (noun) A scroll termination, as of a step, etc.; (verb) To cut short the tail of an animal

daunting.definition: (verb) To discourage, intimidate.; (noun) Present participle of daunt.; (adjective) Discouraging; inspiring fear.
daunting.examples: (adjective) It was a daunting task, but it was accomplished with some forward planning.

dawdle.definition: (noun) A dawdler.; (verb) To spend time idly and unfruitfully, to waste time.
dawdle.examples: (verb) to dawdle away the whole morning

dearth.definition: (noun) A period or condition when food is rare and hence expensive; famine.

debilitating.definition: (verb) To make feeble; to weaken.; (adjective) Causing a loss of energy or strength.
debilitating.examples: (verb) The American Dream suffered a debilitating effect after the subprime crisis.

debunk.definition: (verb) To discredit, or expose to ridicule the falsehood or the exaggerated claims of something.
debunk.examples: (verb) The explosion story was thoroughly debunked on National Public Radio in November 1999.

decadent.definition: (noun) A person affected by moral decay.; (adjective) Characterized by moral or cultural decline.

decipher.definition: (noun) A decipherment; a decoding.; (verb) To decode or decrypt a code or cipher to plain text.

deference.examples: (noun) The children treated their elders with deference.

deflect.definition: (verb) To make (something) deviate from its original path.
deflect.examples: (verb) The Prime Minister deflected some increasingly pointed questions by claiming he had an appointment.

deft.definition: (adjective) Quick and neat in action; skillful.
deft.examples: (adjective) He assembled it in one fluid, deft motion.

deify.definition: (verb) To make a god of (something or someone).

deleterious.definition: (adjective) Harmful often in a subtle or unexpected way.

deliberate.definition: (verb) To consider carefully; to weigh well in the mind.; (adjective) Done on purpose; intentional.
deliberate.examples: (verb) It is now time for the jury to deliberate the guilt of the defendant.; (adjective) Tripping me was deliberate action.

delineate.definition: (verb) To sketch out, draw or trace an outline.

delusion.definition: (noun) A false belief that is resistant to confrontation with actual facts.
delusion.examples: (noun) It is far better to grasp the universe as it really is than to persist in delusion, however satisfying and reassuring.

demur.definition: (noun) Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.; (verb) To linger; to stay; to tarry

denounce.definition: (verb) To make known in a formal manner; to proclaim; to announce; to declare.
denounce.examples: (verb) to denounce someone as a swindler, or as a coward

depose.definition: (verb) To put down; to lay down; to deposit; to lay aside; to put away.
depose.examples: (verb) A deposed monarch may go into exile as pretender to the lost throne, hoping to be restored in a subsequent revolution.

depravity.definition: (noun) The state or condition of being depraved; moral debasement.

deprecate.definition: (verb) To belittle or express disapproval of.
deprecate.examples: (verb) He deprecates any praise of his own merits.

derivative.definition: (noun) Something derived.; (adjective) Obtained by derivation; not radical, original, or fundamental.
derivative.examples: (adjective) a derivative conveyance; a derivative word

desiccate.definition: (noun) A substance which has been dessicated, that is, had its moisture removed.; (verb) To remove moisture from; to dry.; (adjective) Having had moisture removed; dehydrated, dessicated.

despotic.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to a despot or tyrant.
despotic.examples: (adjective) This despotic age of the empire ended in a revolt.

desultory.definition: (adjective) Jumping, or passing, from one thing or subject to another, without order, planning, or rational connection; lacking logical sequence.
desultory.examples: (adjective) He wandered round, cleaning up in a desultory way.

detente.definition: (noun) A relaxing of tension, especially between countries.

deviate.definition: (noun) A person with deviant behaviour; a deviant, degenerate or pervert.; (verb) To go off course from; to change course; to change plans.
deviate.examples: (verb) His exhibition of nude paintings deviated from the norm.

diatribe.definition: (noun) An abusive, bitter, attack or criticism: denunciation.
diatribe.examples: (noun) The senator was prone to diatribes which could go on for more than an hour.

dichotomy.definition: (noun) A separation or division into two; a distinction that results in such a division.

dictate.definition: (noun) An order or command.; (verb) To order, command, control.
dictate.examples: (noun) I must obey the dictates of my conscience.; (verb) She is dictating a letter to a stenographer.

didactic.definition: (noun) A treatise on teaching or education.; (adjective) Instructive or intended to teach or demonstrate, especially with regard to morality.

diffuse.definition: (verb) To spread over or through as in air, water, or other matter, especially by fluid motion or passive means.

digression.definition: (noun) An aside, an act of straying from the main subject in speech or writing.
digression.examples: (noun) The lectures included lengthy digressions on topics ranging from the professor's dog to the meaning of life.

dilatory.definition: (adjective) Relating to dilation; dilative; (adjective) Intentionally delaying (someone or something), intended to cause delay, gain time, or defer decision.

dilettante.definition: (noun) An amateur, someone who dabbles in a field out of casual interest rather than as a profession or serious interest.; (adjective) Pertaining to or like a dilettante.

diminutive.definition: (noun) (grammar) A word form expressing smallness, youth, unimportance, or endearment.; (adjective) Very small.
diminutive.examples: (noun) Booklet, the diminutive of book, means ‘small book’.

dirge.definition: (noun) A mournful poem or piece of music composed or performed as a memorial to a dead person.; (verb) To sing dirges

discernible.definition: (adjective) Possible to discern; detectable or derivable by use of the senses or the intellect.
discernible.examples: (adjective) There is a discernible performance difference between a Porsche and a Civic.

discomfit.definition: (verb) To defeat completely; to rout.; (adjective) Discomfited; overthrown.
discomfit.examples: (verb) Don't worry. Your joke did not really discomfit me.

discount.definition: (noun) A reduction in price.; (verb) To deduct from an account, debt, charge, and the like.; (adjective) (of a store) Specializing in selling goods at reduced prices.
discount.examples: (noun) This store offers discounts on all its wares. That store specializes in discount wares, too.; (verb) Merchants sometimes discount five or six per cent for prompt payment of bills.; (adjective) If you're looking for cheap clothes, there's a discount clothier around the corner.

discreet.definition: (adjective) Respectful of privacy or secrecy; exercising caution in order to avoid causing embarrassment; quiet; diplomatic.
discreet.examples: (adjective) John just doesn't understand that laughing at Mary all day is not very discreet.

discrepancy.definition: (noun) An inconsistency between facts or sentiments.
discrepancy.examples: (noun) They found a discrepancy between the first set of test results and the second, and they're still trying to figure out why.

disdain.definition: (noun) A feeling of contempt or scorn.; (verb) To regard (someone or something) with strong contempt.
disdain.examples: (noun) The cat viewed the cheap supermarket catfood with disdain and stalked away.

disentangle.definition: (verb) To free something from entanglement; to extricate or unknot.
disentangle.examples: (verb) I had to disentangle him from his own shoelaces.

disinterested.definition: (adjective) Having no stake or interest in the outcome; free of bias, impartial.

disparate.definition: (noun) (chiefly in the plural) Any of a group of unequal or dissimilar things.; (adjective) Composed of inherently different or distinct elements; incongruous.
disparate.examples: (adjective) The board of the company was decidedly disparate, with no two members from the same social or economic background.

dispense.definition: (noun) Cost, expenditure.; (verb) To issue, distribute, or give out.

disperse.definition: (verb) To scatter in different directions; (adjective) Scattered or spread out.
disperse.examples: (verb) The Jews are dispersed among all nations.

disseminate.definition: (verb) To sow and scatter principles, ideas, opinions, etc, or concrete things, for growth and propagation, like seeds.
disseminate.examples: (verb) The values of the human rights movement have disseminated throughout the world.

dissent.definition: (noun) Disagreement with the ideas, doctrines, decrees, etc. of a political party, government or religion.; (verb) To disagree; to withhold assent. Construed with from (or, formerly, to).

dissident.definition: (noun) A person who formally opposes the current political structure, the political group in power, the policies of the political group in power, or current laws.; (adjective) In a manner that disagrees; dissenting; discordant.

distend.definition: (verb) To extend or expand, as from internal pressure; to swell

distill.definition: (verb) To subject a substance to distillation.

distort.definition: (verb) To bring something out of shape, to misshape.; (adjective) Distorted; misshapen.
distort.examples: (verb) In their articles, journalists sometimes distort the truth.

distressed.definition: (verb) To cause strain or anxiety to someone.; (adjective) Anxious or uneasy
distressed.examples: (verb) She distressed the new media cabinet so that it fit with the other furniture in the room.; (adjective) I'm distressed that John hasn't answered my calls. I hope nothing bad happened to him on the way here.

divorced.definition: (verb) To legally dissolve a marriage between two people.; (adjective) Cut off, or separated.
divorced.examples: (verb) A ship captain can marry couples, but cannot divorce them.; (adjective) It is a sad fact that 43% of marriages are now divorced.

divulge.definition: (verb) To make public or known; to communicate to the public; to tell (information, especially a secret) so that it may become generally known
divulge.examples: (verb) I will never divulge that secret to anyone.
related_words: let the cat out of the bag

doctrinaire.definition: (noun) A person who stubbornly holds to a philosophy or opinion regardless of its feasibility.; (adjective) Stubbornly holding on to an idea without concern for practicalities or reality.

documentary.definition: (noun) A film, TV program, publication etc. which presents a social, political, scientific or historical subject in a factual or informative manner.; (adjective) Of, related to, or based on documents.

dogged.definition: (verb) To pursue with the intent to catch.
dogged.examples: (verb) The woman cursed him so that trouble would dog his every step.

dogmatic.definition: (noun) One of an ancient sect of physicians who went by general principles; opposed to the empiric.; (adjective) Adhering only to principles which are true a priori, rather than truths based on evidence or deduction.

dowdy.definition: (noun) A plain or shabby person; (adjective) Plain and unfashionable in style or dress.

droll.definition: (noun) A funny person; a buffoon, a wag.; (verb) To jest, to joke.; (adjective) Oddly humorous; whimsical, amusing in a quaint way; waggish.

dubious.definition: (adjective) (of a statement) Arousing doubt; questionable; open to suspicion.
dubious.examples: (adjective) After he made some dubious claims about the company, fewer people trusted him.

dupe.definition: (noun) A person who has been deceived.; (verb) To swindle, deceive, or trick.

duplicitous.definition: (adjective) Given to or marked by deliberate deceptiveness in behavior or speech.

duress.definition: (noun) Harsh treatment.; (verb) To put under duress; to pressure.

dwindling.definition: (verb) To decrease, shrink, diminish, reduce in size or intensity.; (noun) A gradual reduction to nothing.; (adjective) Declining; growing less
dwindling.examples: (adjective) There is dwindling support for New Labour.

eccentric.definition: (noun) One who does not behave like others.; (adjective) Not at or in the centre; away from the centre.
eccentric.examples: (adjective) As of 2008, Margaret had the most eccentric orbit of any moon in the solar system, though Nereid's mean eccentricity is greater.

echelon.definition: (noun) A level or rank in an organization, profession, or society.; (verb) To form troops into an echelon.; (adjective) Of a matrix: having undergone Gaussian elimination with the result that the leading coefficient or pivot (that is, the first nonzero number from the left) of a nonzero row is to the right of the pivot of the row above it, giving rise to a stepped appearance in the matrix.

eclectic.definition: (noun) Someone who selects according to the eclectic method.; (adjective) Selecting a mixture of what appears to be best of various doctrines, methods or styles.

eclipse.definition: (noun) An alignment of astronomical objects whereby one object comes between the observer (or notional observer) and another object, thus obscuring the latter.; (verb) Of astronomical bodies, to cause an eclipse.

economy.definition: (noun) Effective management of a community or system, or especially its resources.; (adjective) Cheap to run; using minimal resources; representing good value for money.

effrontery.examples: (noun) We even had the effrontery to suggest that he should leave the country.

egregious.definition: (adjective) Usually in a negative sense: conspicuous, exceptional, outstanding.
egregious.examples: (adjective) The student has made egregious errors on the examination.

elated.definition: (verb) To make joyful or proud.; (adjective) Extremely happy and excited; delighted; pleased, euphoric.
elated.examples: (adjective) She was elated with her new car.

elementary.definition: (noun) An elementary school; (adjective) Relating to the basic, essential or fundamental part of something.

elicit.definition: (verb) To evoke, educe (emotions, feelings, responses, etc.); to generate, obtain, or provoke as a response or answer.; (adjective) Elicited; drawn out; made real; open; evident.

elitist.definition: (noun) (usually derogatory) Someone who believes in or is perceived as believing in rule by an elite group.; (adjective) Of or relating to elitism.

elucidate.definition: (verb) To make clear; to clarify; to shed light upon.

embellish.definition: (verb) To make more beautiful and attractive; to decorate.
embellish.examples: (verb) The old book cover was embellished with golden letters

empirical.definition: (adjective) Pertaining to or based on experience.

emulate.definition: (verb) To attempt to equal or be the same as.; (adjective) Striving to excel; ambitious; emulous.

enchant.definition: (verb) To attract and delight, to charm.

encyclopedic.definition: (adjective) Of or relating to the characteristics of an encyclopedia; concerning all subjects, having comprehensive information or knowledge.

endemic.definition: (noun) An individual or species that is endemic to a region.; (adjective) Native to a particular area or culture; originating where it occurs.
endemic.examples: (adjective) The endemic religion of Easter Island arrived with the Polynesian settlers.

endow.definition: (verb) To provide with a dower or a dowry.
endow.examples: (verb) She was endowed with a beautiful voice.

enervate.definition: (verb) To reduce strength or energy; debilitate.; (adjective) Made feeble; weakened.
enervate.examples: (verb) After being laid off three times in a row, she felt too enervated to look for another job.

engender.definition: (verb) To beget (of a man); to bear or conceive (of a woman).

enmity.definition: (noun) The quality of being an enemy; hostile or unfriendly disposition.

ennui.definition: (noun) A gripping listlessness or melancholia caused by boredom; depression.; (verb) To make bored or listless; to weary.

enthrall.definition: (verb) To hold spellbound; to bewitch, charm or captivate.

entitled.definition: (verb) To give a title to.; (adjective) Having a title.
entitled.examples: (verb) A passport entitles the bearer to travel to other countries.; (adjective) Her book is entitled 'My Autobiography'.

entreat.definition: (noun) An entreaty.; (verb) To treat with, or in respect to, a thing desired; hence, to ask for earnestly.

entrenched.definition: (verb) To dig or excavate a trench; to trench.
entrenched.examples: (verb) The army entrenched its camp, or entrenched itself.

ephemeral.definition: (noun) Something which lasts for a short period of time.; (adjective) Lasting for a short period of time.

equanimity.definition: (noun) The state of being calm, stable and composed, especially under stress.

equivocate.definition: (verb) To use words of equivocal or doubtful signification; to express one's opinions in terms which admit of different senses, with intent to deceive; to use ambiguous expressions with a view to mislead; as, to equivocate is the work of duplicity.

eradicate.definition: (verb) To pull up by the roots; to uproot.

erratic.definition: (noun) A rock moved from one location to another, usually by a glacier.; (adjective) Unsteady, random; prone to unexpected changes; not consistent
erratic.examples: (adjective) Henry has been getting erratic scores on his tests: 40% last week, but 98% this week.

erudite.definition: (noun) A learned or scholarly person; (adjective) Learned, scholarly, with emphasis on knowledge gained from books.

escalate.definition: (verb) To increase (something) in extent or intensity; to intensify or step up.
escalate.examples: (verb) The shooting escalated the existing hostility.

eschew.definition: (verb) To avoid; to shun, to shy away from.

esoteric.definition: (noun) An esoteric doctrine or treatise; esoteric philosophy.; (adjective) Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest, or an enlightened inner circle.
esoteric.examples: (adjective) The writing in this manual is very esoteric; I’d need a degree in engineering just to understand it!

estranged.definition: (verb) To cause to feel less close or friendly; alienate. To cease contact with (particularly of a family member or spouse, especially in form estranged).; (adjective) Having become a stranger, of one who formerly was close, as a relative, friend, lover, or spouse.

euphemism.definition: (noun) The use of a word or phrase to replace another with one that is considered less offensive, blunt or vulgar than the word or phrase which it replaces.

euphoric.definition: (noun) A drug that causes euphoria; a euphoriant.; (adjective) Feeling great well-being or elation or intense happiness; characterized by euphoria
euphoric.examples: (adjective) In this moment, I am euphoric.

evade.definition: (verb) To get away from by cunning; to avoid by dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to cleverly escape from

evasive.definition: (adjective) Tending to avoid speaking openly or making revelations about oneself.

evoke.definition: (verb) To call out; to draw out or bring forth.
evoke.examples: (verb) Being here evokes long forgotten memories.

exacerbate.definition: (verb) To make worse (a problem, bad situation, negative feeling, etc.); aggravate; exasperate.
exacerbate.examples: (verb) The proposed shutdown would exacerbate unemployment problems.

exacting.definition: (verb) To demand and enforce the payment or performance of, sometimes in a forcible or imperious way.; (adjective) Making excessive demands; difficult to satisfy.
exacting.examples: (verb) to exact tribute, fees, or obedience from someone

exasperated.definition: (verb) To tax the patience of, irk, frustrate, vex, provoke, annoy; to make angry.; (adjective) Having one's patience greatly taxed; greatly annoyed; made furious.

excoriate.definition: (verb) To wear off the skin of; to chafe or flay.

exculpate.definition: (verb) To clear of or to free from guilt; exonerate.

exhilarating.definition: (verb) To cheer, to cheer up, to gladden, to make happy.; (adjective) Refreshingly thrilling.
exhilarating.examples: (verb) Good news exhilarates the mind; wine exhilarates the drinker.

exigent.definition: (noun) Extremity; end; limit; pressing urgency.; (adjective) Urgent; needing immediate action.

exonerate.definition: (verb) To relieve (someone or something) of a load; to unburden (a load).; (adjective) Freed from an obligation; freed from accusation or blame; acquitted, exonerated.

exorbitant.definition: (adjective) Exceeding proper limits; extravagant; excessive or unduly high.
exorbitant.examples: (adjective) It's a nice car, but they are charging an exorbitant price for it.

exorcize.definition: (verb) To drive out supposed evil spirits from a person, place or thing, especially by an incantation or prayer

exotic.definition: (noun) An organism that is exotic to an environment.; (adjective) Foreign, especially in an exciting way.
exotic.examples: (noun) Glueballs, theoretical particles composed only of gluons, are exotics.; (adjective) an exotic appearance

expatiate.definition: (verb) To range at large, or without restraint.

expedient.definition: (noun) A method or means for achieving a particular result, especially when direct or efficient; a resource.; (adjective) Suitable to effect some desired end or the purpose intended.
expedient.examples: (adjective) Most people, faced with a decision, will choose the most expedient option.

expedite.definition: (verb) To accelerate the progress of.; (adjective) Free of impediment; unimpeded.
expedite.examples: (verb) He expedited the search by alphabetizing the papers.

exploitative.definition: (adjective) In the nature of exploitation; acting to exploit someone or something
exploitative.examples: (adjective) We are protesting the company's exploitative policies.

extemporize.definition: (verb) To do something, particularly to perform or speak, without prior planning or thought; to act in an impromptu manner; to improvise.

extenuating.definition: (verb) To lessen; to palliate; to lessen or weaken the force of; to diminish the conception of, as crime, guilt, faults, ills, accusations, etc.; (adjective) That lessens the seriousness of something by providing an excuse.

extraneous.definition: (adjective) Not belonging to, or dependent upon, a thing; without or beyond a thing; foreign
extraneous.examples: (adjective) Extraneous substances were found on my cup of water.

extrapolate.definition: (verb) To infer by extending known information.

extravagant.definition: (adjective) Exceeding the bounds of something; roving; hence, foreign.

fabricate.definition: (verb) To form into a whole by uniting its parts; to construct; to build.
fabricate.examples: (verb) to fabricate a bridge or ship

facetious.definition: (adjective) Treating serious issues with (often deliberately) inappropriate humour; flippant.
facetious.examples: (adjective) Robbie's joke about Heather's appearance was just him being facetious.

factious.definition: (adjective) Of, pertaining to, or caused by factions.

fallacious.definition: (adjective) Characterized by fallacy; false or mistaken.

fallible.definition: (adjective) Capable of making mistakes or being wrong.

fallow.definition: (noun) Ground ploughed and harrowed but left unseeded for one year.; (adjective) (of agricultural land) Ploughed but left unseeded for more than one planting season.
fallow.examples: (adjective) a fallow period in one's career

falter.definition: (noun) Unsteadiness.; (verb) To waver or be unsteady; to weaken or trail off.

fastidious.definition: (adjective) Excessively particular, demanding, or fussy about details, especially about tidiness and cleanliness.

fawn.definition: (noun) A young deer.; (verb) To give birth to a fawn.; (adjective) Of the fawn colour.

feasible.definition: (adjective) Able to be done in practice.
feasible.examples: (adjective) His plan to rid Trafalgar Square of pigeons by bringing in peregrine falcons to eat them was dismissed as not feasible.

fecund.definition: (adjective) Highly fertile; able to produce offspring.

feeble.definition: (verb) To make feeble; to enfeeble.; (adjective) Deficient in physical strength
feeble.examples: (adjective) Though she appeared old and feeble, she could still throw a ball.

feign.definition: (verb) To make a false show or pretence of; to counterfeit or simulate.
feign.examples: (verb) The pupil feigned sickness on the day of his exam.

feint.definition: (noun) A movement made to confuse the opponent; a dummy.; (verb) To make a feint, or mock attack.; (adjective) Feigned; counterfeit.

felicitous.examples: (adjective) This sentence is grammatical; it is just not felicitous.

fervent.definition: (adjective) Exhibiting particular enthusiasm, zeal, conviction, persistence, or belief.

fervor.definition: (noun) An intense, heated emotion; passion, ardor.
fervor.examples: (noun) The coach trains his water polo team with fervor.

fester.definition: (noun) A fistula.; (verb) To become septic; to become rotten.
fester.examples: (verb) Deal with the problem immediately; do not let it fester.

fickle.definition: (adjective) Quick to change one’s opinion or allegiance; insincere; not loyal or reliable.

figurative.definition: (adjective) Of use as a metaphor, simile, or metonym, as opposed to literal; using figures; as when saying that someone who eats more than they should is a pig or like a pig.

finicky.definition: (adjective) (of a person) Fastidious and fussy; difficult to please; exacting, especially about details.
finicky.examples: (adjective) My editor is very finicky about punctuation. Every dot and comma has to be just right.

flamboyant.definition: (noun) The royal poinciana (Delonix regia), a showy tropical tree.; (adjective) Showy, bold or audacious in behaviour, appearance, etc.

fledgling.definition: (noun) A young bird which has just developed its flight feathers (notably wings).; (adjective) Untried or inexperienced.

florid.definition: (adjective) Having a rosy or pale red colour; ruddy.

flout.definition: (noun) The act by which something is flouted; violation of a law.; (verb) To express contempt for (laws, rules, etc.) by word or action.

flummoxed.definition: (verb) To confuse; to fluster; to flabbergast.; (adjective) Confused, perplexed or flustered.
flummoxed.examples: (adjective) He's good at what he knows, but he gets completely flummoxed when new problems arise.

flustered.definition: (verb) To make hot and rosy, as with drinking.; (adjective) Confused, befuddled, in a state of panic by having become overwrought with confusion.
flustered.examples: (verb) He seemed to get flustered when speaking in front of too many people.; (adjective) The speaker became quite flustered when she dropped all her notes.

foil.definition: (noun) A very thin sheet of metal.; (verb) To cover or wrap with foil.
foil.examples: (noun) wrap the sandwich up in foil

foment.definition: (noun) Fomentation.; (verb) To incite or cause troublesome acts; to encourage; to instigate.
foment.examples: (verb) Foreign governments have tried to foment unrest.

foolhardy.definition: (adjective) Marked by unthinking recklessness with disregard for danger; boldly rash; hotheaded.

forbear.definition: (verb) To keep away from; to avoid; to abstain from.

foreseeable.definition: (adjective) Able to be foreseen or anticipated
foreseeable.examples: (adjective) This project will not be finished in the foreseeable future.

forestall.definition: (verb) To prevent, delay or hinder something by taking precautionary or anticipatory measures; to avert.
forestall.examples: (verb) Fred forestalled disaster by his prompt action.

forsake.definition: (verb) To abandon, to give up, to leave (permanently), to renounce.

fortitude.definition: (noun) Mental or emotional strength that enables courage in the face of adversity.

frailty.definition: (noun) The condition quality of being frail, physically, mentally, or morally; weakness of resolution; liability to be deceived or seduced.

fraught.definition: (noun) The hire of a ship or boat to transport cargo.

frenetic.definition: (noun) One who is frenetic.; (adjective) Fast, harried; having extreme enthusiasm or energy.
frenetic.examples: (adjective) After a week of working at a frenetic pace, she was ready for Saturday.

fret.definition: (noun) Agitation of the surface of a fluid by fermentation or some other cause; a rippling on the surface of water.; (verb) Especially when describing animals: to consume, devour, or eat.
fret.examples: (noun) He keeps his mind in a continual fret.; (verb) to fret the surface of water

fringe.definition: (noun) Hair hanging over the forehead.; (noun) Brucellosis, a bacterial disease.; (noun) A decorative border.; (verb) To decorate with fringe.; (adjective) Outside the mainstream.

frivolous.definition: (adjective) Silly, especially at an inappropriate time or in an inappropriate manner.

fruitful.definition: (adjective) Favourable to the growth of fruit or useful vegetation; not barren.
fruitful.examples: (adjective) The extra work in the office turned out to be fruitful after all—I got promoted

fulcrum.definition: (noun) The support about which a lever pivots.
fulcrum.examples: (noun) It is possible to flick food across the table using your fork as a lever and your finger as a fulcrum.

fungible.definition: (noun) (chiefly in the plural) Any fungible item.; (adjective) Able to be substituted for something of equal value or utility; interchangeable, exchangeable, replaceable.

futile.definition: (adjective) Incapable of producing results; doomed not to be successful; not worth attempting.

gaffe.definition: (noun) A foolish and embarrassing error, especially one made in public.

gainsay.definition: (verb) To say something in contradiction to.

galvanize.definition: (verb) To coat with a thin layer of metal by electrochemical means.

gauche.definition: (adjective) Awkward or lacking in social graces; bumbling.

gawky.definition: (noun) An awkward, ungainly person.; (adjective) Awkward, ungainly; lacking grace or dexterity in movement

glib.definition: (verb) To make glib.; (adjective) Having a ready flow of words but lacking thought or understanding; superficial; shallow.

goad.definition: (noun) A long, pointed stick used to prod animals.; (verb) To prod with a goad.

gregarious.definition: (adjective) (of a person) Describing one who enjoys being in crowds and socializing.

grievance.examples: (noun) If you want the problem fixed, you'll have to file a grievance with the city.

grovel.definition: (verb) To be prone on the ground.

gullible.definition: (noun) A gullible person; someone easily fooled or tricked.; (adjective) Easily deceived or duped; naive, easily cheated or fooled.
gullible.examples: (adjective) Andrew is so gullible, the way he still believes in Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny, the Tooth Fairy, and the Sandman at the age of fourteen.

hackneyed.definition: (verb) To make uninteresting or trite by frequent use.; (adjective) Repeated too often.
hackneyed.examples: (adjective) The sermon was full of hackneyed phrases and platitudes.

hamper.definition: (noun) A large basket, usually with a cover, used for the packing and carrying of articles or small animals; (verb) To put into a hamper.
hamper.examples: (noun) a clothes hamper; (verb) Competition pigeons are hampered for the truck trip to the point of release where the race back starts.

haphazard.definition: (adjective) Random; chaotic; incomplete; not thorough, constant, or consistent.
haphazard.examples: (adjective) Do not make such haphazard changes to the settings; instead, adjust the knobs carefully, a bit at a time.

harangue.definition: (noun) An impassioned, disputatious public speech.; (verb) To give a forceful and lengthy lecture or criticism to someone.
harangue.examples: (noun) She gave her son a harangue about the dangers of playing in the street.; (verb) The angry motorist leapt from his car to harangue the other driver.

harbinger.definition: (noun) A person or thing that foreshadows or foretells the coming of someone or something.; (verb) To announce or precede; to be a harbinger of.

haughty.definition: (adjective) Conveying in demeanour the assumption of superiority; disdainful, supercilious.

headstrong.definition: (adjective) Determined to do as one pleases, and not as others want.
headstrong.examples: (adjective) He was in that headstrong teenage phase when he felt like he knew everything.

heady.examples: (adjective) The cocktail was a heady mixture of spirits.

heterodox.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to creeds, beliefs, or teachings, especially religious ones, that are different from orthodoxy, or the norm, but not sufficiently different to be called heretical.
heterodox.examples: (adjective) The Church of Alexandria in Egypt is considered heterodox, not heretical.

heterogeneous.definition: (adjective) Diverse in kind or nature; composed of diverse parts.
heterogeneous.examples: (adjective) He had a large and heterogeneous collection of books.

hinder.definition: (verb) To make difficult to accomplish; to act as an obstacle; to frustrate.
hinder.examples: (verb) A drought hinders the growth of plants.

histrionic.definition: (adjective) Of or relating to actors or acting.

hodgepodge.definition: (noun) A hotchpotch; a collection containing a variety of miscellaneous things.; (verb) To move or position in an erratic, disorganised manner.
hodgepodge.examples: (noun) His latest sculpture is a hodgepodge of kitchen clutter and scrap glued together.

homogeneous.definition: (adjective) Of the same kind; alike, similar.

humdrum.definition: (noun) The quality of lacking variety or excitement.; (adjective) Lacking variety or excitement; dull; boring.

hyperbole.definition: (noun) Deliberate or unintentional overstatement, particularly extreme overstatement.

iconoclastic.definition: (adjective) Characterized by attack on established and accepted beliefs, customs, or institutions; of or pertaining to iconoclasm.
iconoclastic.examples: (adjective) Many of Thomas Hardy's works were considered iconoclastic in his day.

idiosyncratic.definition: (adjective) Peculiar to a specific individual; eccentric.

illusory.definition: (adjective) Resulting from an illusion; deceptive, imaginary, unreal

immaculate.definition: (adjective) Having no stain or blemish; spotless, undefiled, clear, clean, pure.
immaculate.examples: (adjective) Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain. — Shakespeare, Richard II, V-iii.

imminent.definition: (adjective) About to happen, occur, or take place very soon, especially of something which won't last long.

immure.definition: (noun) A wall; an enclosure.; (verb) To cloister, confine, imprison: to lock up behind walls.
immure.examples: (verb) John's body was immured Thursday in the mausoleum.

immutable.definition: (noun) Something that cannot be changed; (adjective) Unable to be changed without exception.
immutable.examples: (adjective) The government has enacted an immutable law.

impair.definition: (verb) To weaken; to affect negatively; to have a diminishing effect on.; (adjective) Not fit or appropriate; unsuitable.

impede.definition: (verb) To get in the way of; to hinder.

imperturbable.definition: (adjective) Not easily perturbed, upset or excited.

impetuous.definition: (adjective) Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.

implacable.definition: (adjective) Not able to be placated or appeased.

implicit.definition: (adjective) Implied indirectly, without being directly expressed

improvise.definition: (verb) To make something up or invent it as one goes on; to proceed guided only by imagination, instinct, and guesswork rather than by a careful plan.
improvise.examples: (verb) He had no speech prepared, so he improvised.

impudent.definition: (adjective) Not showing due respect; impertinent; bold-faced.
impudent.examples: (adjective) The impudent children would not stop talking in class.

inborn.definition: (adjective) Innate, possessed by an organism at birth.

incendiary.definition: (noun) Something capable of causing fire, particularly a weapon.; (adjective) Capable of, or used for, or actually causing fire.
incendiary.examples: (noun) The military used incendiaries to destroy the building. Fortunately, the fire didn't spread.; (adjective) Politics is an incendiary topic; it tends to cause fights to break out.

incessant.definition: (adjective) Without pause or stop; not ending, especially to the point of annoyance.
incessant.examples: (adjective) The dog's incessant barking kept the girl awake all night.

inchoate.definition: (noun) A beginning, an immature start.; (verb) To begin or start (something).; (adjective) Recently started but not fully formed yet; just begun; only elementary or immature.

incidental.definition: (noun) Minor items, not further defined. Incidental expense.; (adjective) Loosely associated; existing as a byproduct, tangent, or accident; being a likely consequence.
incidental.examples: (noun) She's costing us a lot in incidentals.; (adjective) That character, though colorful, is incidental to the overall plot.

inclined.definition: (verb) To bend or move (something) out of a given plane or direction, often the horizontal or vertical.; (adjective) At an angle to the horizontal; slanted or sloped.
inclined.examples: (verb) He had to incline his body against the gusts to avoid being blown down in the storm.; (adjective) The take-off ramp was inclined at 20 degrees.

incongruous.definition: (adjective) Not similar or congruent; not matching or fitting in.
incongruous.examples: (adjective) 20 and 25 are incongruous with respect to 4.

incontrovertible.definition: (adjective) Not capable of being denied, challenged, or disputed; closed to questioning.
incontrovertible.examples: (adjective) Her statement that Hitler was evil is incontrovertible.

incredulous.definition: (adjective) Skeptical, disbelieving, or unable to believe.

indictment.definition: (noun) An official formal accusation for a criminal offence, or the process by which it is brought to a jury.

indignant.definition: (adjective) Showing anger or indignation, especially at something unjust or wrong.

indiscriminate.definition: (adjective) Without care or making distinctions, thoughtless.
indiscriminate.examples: (adjective) How can anyone be so indiscriminate in making friends as he is?

indispensable.definition: (noun) A thing that is not dispensable; a necessity.; (adjective) Not admitting ecclesiastical dispensation; not subject to release or exemption; that cannot be allowed by bending the canonical rules.
indispensable.examples: (adjective) The law was moral and indispensable. -Bp. Burnet

indolent.definition: (adjective) Habitually lazy, procrastinating, or resistant to physical labor
indolent.examples: (adjective) The indolent girl resisted doing her homework.

industrious.examples: (adjective) I was very industrious in my effort to learn unicycle riding.

ineluctable.definition: (adjective) Impossible to avoid or escape; inescapable, irresistible.

inform.definition: (verb) To instruct, train (usually in matters of knowledge).
inform.examples: (verb) His sense of religion informs everything he writes.

ingrained.definition: (verb) To dye with a fast or lasting colour.; (adjective) Being an element; present in the essence of a thing
ingrained.examples: (verb) The dirt was deeply ingrained in the carpet.

inhibit.definition: (verb) To hold in or hold back; to keep in check; restrain.

inscrutable.definition: (noun) One who or that which is inscrutable; a person, etc. that cannot be comprehended.; (adjective) Difficult or impossible to comprehend, fathom or interpret.
inscrutable.examples: (adjective) His inscrutable theories would years later become the foundation of a whole new science.

insipid.examples: (adjective) The diners were disappointed with the plain, insipid soup they were served.

insolent.definition: (noun) A person who is insolent.; (adjective) Insulting in manner or words.

insular.definition: (noun) An islander.; (adjective) Of, pertaining to, being, or resembling an island or islands.

interchangeable.definition: (noun) Anything that can be interchanged; a substitute.; (adjective) Freely substitutable; that may be swapped at will.
interchangeable.examples: (adjective) Eli Whitney's development of interchangeable parts was a breakthrough for modern manufacturing. Prior to that, each part had to be made custom.

intermittent.definition: (noun) An intermittent fever or disease.; (adjective) Stopping and starting, occuring, or presenting at intervals; coming after a particular time span.
intermittent.examples: (adjective) Intermittent bugs are most difficult to reproduce.

intertwined.definition: (verb) To twine something together.; (adjective) Twined or twisted together

intimate.definition: (noun) A very close friend.; (verb) To suggest or disclose (something) discreetly.; (adjective) Closely acquainted; familiar.
intimate.examples: (noun) Only a couple of intimates had ever read his writing.; (verb) He intimated that we should leave before the argument escalated.; (adjective) He and his sister deeply valued their intimate relationship as they didn't have much else to live for.

intransigent.definition: (noun) A person who is intransigent.; (adjective) Unwilling to compromise or moderate a position; unreasonable
intransigent.examples: (adjective) Don't waste your time trying to change his mind: he's completely intransigent.

intrigue.definition: (noun) A complicated or clandestine plot or scheme intended to effect some purpose by secret artifice; conspiracy; stratagem.; (verb) To conceive or carry out a secret plan intended to harm; to form a plot or scheme.

intrinsic.definition: (noun) A built-in function that is implemented directly by the compiler, without any intermediate call to a library.; (adjective) Innate, inherent, inseparable from the thing itself, essential.
intrinsic.examples: (noun) You can acquire the fire-resistance intrinsic by eating dragon meat.; (adjective) the intrinsic merit of an action

inundate.definition: (verb) To cover with large amounts of water; to flood.
inundate.examples: (verb) The Dutch would sometimes inundate the land to hinder the Spanish army.

invasive.definition: (noun) An invasive organism, as, a plant or animal.; (adjective) That invades a foreign country using military force.

inveigle.definition: (verb) To convert, convince, or win over with flattery or wiles.
inveigle.examples: (verb) He inveigled an introduction to her.

inveterate.definition: (verb) To fix and settle after a long time; to entrench.; (adjective) Firmly established from having been around for a long time; of long standing

invidious.definition: (adjective) Causing ill will, envy, or offense.

invigorate.definition: (verb) To impart vigor, strength, or vitality to.

inviolate.definition: (adjective) Not violated; free from violation or hurt of any kind; secure against violation or impairment.

irascible.definition: (adjective) Easily provoked to outbursts of anger; irritable.

irksome.definition: (adjective) Marked by irritation or annoyance; disagreeable; troublesome by reason of long continuance or repetition
irksome.examples: (adjective) He has this irksome habit of racing up to red lights, so he has to brake heavily.

ironclad.definition: (noun) A metal-plated ship, vessel, or vehicle.; (adjective) Covered with iron, steel, or some metal, armor-plated.
ironclad.examples: (adjective) The suspect had an ironclad alibi for his whereabouts on the night of the crime.

irresolute.definition: (adjective) Undecided or unsure how to act

irreverent.definition: (adjective) Lacking respect; not having or not showing respect for or seriousness towards something that is usually treated with respect; going against conventional precepts.

itinerant.definition: (noun) One who travels from place to place.; (adjective) Habitually travelling from place to place.

jeopardize.definition: (verb) To put in jeopardy, to threaten.
jeopardize.examples: (verb) After having an affair with a junior, her chances of promotion were seriously jeopardized.

jettison.definition: (noun) (collective) Items that have been or are about to be ejected from a boat or balloon.; (verb) To eject from a boat, submarine, aircraft, spaceship or hot-air balloon, so as to lighten the load.
jettison.examples: (verb) The ballooners had to jettison all of their sand bags to make it over the final hill.

jocund.definition: (adjective) Jovial; exuberant; lighthearted; merry and in high spirits; exhibiting happiness.

judicious.definition: (adjective) Having, characterized by, or done with good judgment or sound thinking.

laconic.definition: (adjective) Using as few words as possible; pithy and concise.

lambaste.definition: (verb) To scold, reprimand or criticize harshly.
lambaste.examples: (verb) Her first novel was well and truly lambasted by the critics.

lament.definition: (noun) An expression of grief, suffering, sadness or regret.; (verb) To express grief; to weep or wail; to mourn.

lampoon.definition: (noun) A written attack or other work ridiculing a person, group, or institution.; (verb) To satirize or poke fun at.
