languid.definition: (adjective) Lacking enthusiasm, energy, or strength; drooping or flagging from weakness, fatigue, or lack of energy

languish.definition: (verb) To lose strength and become weak; to be in a state of weakness or sickness.

largesse.definition: (noun) Generosity in the giving of gifts or money.

latitude.definition: (noun) The angular distance north or south from a planet's equator, measured along the meridian of that particular point.
latitude.examples: (noun) His parents gave him a great deal of latitude.

laudable.definition: (adjective) Worthy of being lauded; praiseworthy; commendable

lavish.definition: (verb) To give out extremely generously; to squander.; (adjective) Expending or bestowing profusely; profuse; prodigal.
lavish.examples: (verb) They lavished money on the dinner.; (adjective) lavish of money;   lavish of praise

levity.definition: (noun) Lightness of manner or speech, frivolity; lack of appropriate seriousness; inclination to make a joke of serious matters.

liability.definition: (noun) An obligation, debt or responsibility owed to someone.

libertine.definition: (noun) Someone freed from slavery in Ancient Rome; a freedman.

limpid.examples: (adjective) The limpid glass doors reveal the living room clearly from the dining room.

lionize.definition: (verb) To treat (a person) as if they were important, or a celebrity.

lucid.definition: (noun) A lucid dream.; (adjective) Clear; easily understood

lugubrious.definition: (adjective) Gloomy, mournful or dismal, especially to an exaggerated degree.
lugubrious.examples: (adjective) His client’s lugubrious expression tipped off the detective that something lurked beneath her optimistic words.

lull.definition: (noun) A period of rest or soothing.; (verb) To cause to rest by soothing influences; to compose; to calm

magisterial.definition: (adjective) Befitting the status or skill of a magister or master; authoritative, masterly.

magnanimous.examples: (adjective) He thinks himself ardent, impulsive, passionate, magnanimous — capable of boundless enthusiasm for an idea or a sentiment.

malevolent.definition: (adjective) Having or displaying ill will; wishing harm on others

malign.definition: (verb) To make defamatory statements about; to slander or traduce.; (adjective) Evil or malignant in disposition, nature, intent or influence.

malleable.definition: (adjective) Able to be hammered into thin sheets; capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer, or by the pressure of rollers.
malleable.examples: (adjective) My opinion on the subject is malleable.

manacle.definition: (noun) A shackle for the wrist, usually consisting of a pair of joined rings; a handcuff; (by extension) a similar device put around an ankle to restrict free movement.; (verb) To confine with manacles.

manifest.definition: (noun) A list or invoice of the passengers or goods being carried by a commercial vehicle or ship.; (verb) To show plainly; to make to appear distinctly, usually to the mind; to put beyond question or doubt; to display; to exhibit.; (adjective) Evident to the senses, especially to the sight; apparent; distinctly perceived.
manifest.examples: (verb) His courage manifested itself through the look on his face.

marginalize.definition: (verb) To relegate (something, especially a topic or a group of people) to the margins or to a lower limit; to exclude socially or otherwise.

mediate.definition: (verb) To resolve differences, or to bring about a settlement, between conflicting parties.; (adjective) Acting through a mediating agency, indirect.

mendacity.definition: (noun) The fact or condition of being untruthful; dishonesty.

mercenary.definition: (noun) One motivated by gain, especially monetary.; (adjective) Motivated by private gain.

mercurial.definition: (noun) Any of the plants known as mercury, especially the annual mercury or French mercury (Mercurialis annua).; (adjective) Having a lively or volatile character; animated, changeable, quick-witted.

meritorious.definition: (adjective) Deserving of merit or commendation; deserving reward.
meritorious.examples: (adjective) The policeman received the Award of Meritorious Service from his grateful department.

metaphorical.definition: (adjective) Pertaining to or characterized by a metaphor; figurative; symbolic.

meticulous.definition: (adjective) Characterized by very precise, conscientious attention to details.

mettlesome.definition: (adjective) Marked by mettle or bravery; courageous.

mimic.definition: (noun) A person who practices mimicry, or mime.; (verb) To imitate, especially in order to ridicule.; (adjective) Pertaining to mimicry; imitative.

minute.definition: (noun) A unit of time equal to sixty seconds (one-sixtieth of an hour).; (verb) Of an event, to write in a memo or the minutes of a meeting.
minute.examples: (noun) You have twenty minutes to complete the test.; (verb) I’ll minute this evening’s meeting.

miscreant.definition: (noun) One who has behaved badly, or illegally.; (adjective) Lacking in conscience or moral principles; unscrupulous.
miscreant.examples: (noun) The teacher sent the miscreants to see the school principal.

miserly.definition: (adjective) Like a miser; very covetous; cautious with money

misnomer.definition: (noun) A use of a term that is misleading; a misname.; (verb) To use a misleading term; to misname.
misnomer.examples: (noun) Calling it a driveway is a bit of a misnomer, since you don't drive on it, you park on it.

mitigate.definition: (verb) To reduce, lessen, or decrease; to make less severe or easier to bear.

modest.definition: (adjective) Not bragging or boasting about oneself or one's achievements; unpretentious, humble.
modest.examples: (adjective) He earns a modest amount of money.

mollify.definition: (verb) To ease a burden, particularly worry; make less painful; to comfort.

monotonous.definition: (adjective) Having an unvarying tone or pitch.

mordant.definition: (noun) Any substance used to facilitate the fixing of a dye to a fibre; usually a metallic compound which reacts with the dye using chelation.; (verb) To subject to the action of, or imbue with, a mordant.; (adjective) Having or showing a sharp or critical quality

morose.definition: (adjective) Sullen, gloomy; showing a brooding ill humour.

mundane.definition: (noun) An unremarkable, ordinary human being.; (adjective) Worldly, earthly, profane, vulgar as opposed to heavenly.

munificent.definition: (adjective) (of a person or group) Very liberal in giving or bestowing.

mutiny.definition: (noun) An organized rebellion against a legally constituted authority, especially by seamen against their officers.; (verb) To commit mutiny.
mutiny.examples: (verb) The crew of the Bounty mutinied because of the harsh discipline of Captain Bligh.

myopic.definition: (noun) A short-sighted individual.; (adjective) Near-sighted; unable to see distant objects unaided
myopic.examples: (adjective) A stronger prescription for myopic night drivers is often needed.

nadir.definition: (noun) The point of the celestial sphere, directly opposite the zenith; inferior pole of the horizon; point of the celestial sphere directly under the place of observation.; (verb) To extend (a beehive) by adding an empty box at the base.
nadir.examples: (noun) The nadir of the sun is the axis of the shadow projected by the Earth.

naive.definition: (noun) A naive person; a greenhorn.; (adjective) Lacking worldly experience, wisdom, or judgement; unsophisticated.

negligent.definition: (adjective) Careless, without appropriate or sufficient attention.

neophyte.definition: (noun) A beginner; a person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief.

nettlesome.definition: (adjective) (of a person, thing, situation, etc.) Causing irritation, annoyance, or discomfort; bothersome, irksome.
nettlesome.examples: (adjective) My poison ivy rash is very nettlesome.

neutralize.definition: (verb) To make even, inactive or ineffective.

noble.definition: (noun) An aristocrat; one of aristocratic blood.; (adjective) Having honorable qualities; having moral eminence and freedom from anything petty, mean or dubious in conduct and character.
noble.examples: (noun) This country house was occupied by nobles in the 16th century.; (adjective) He is a noble man who would never put his family in jeopardy.

nominal.definition: (noun) (grammar) A noun or word group that functions as part of a noun phrase.; (adjective) Of, resembling, relating to, or consisting of a name or names.
nominal.examples: (noun) This sentence contains two nominals.; (adjective) a nominal difference

nonchalant.examples: (adjective) We handled the whole frenetic situation with a nonchalant attitude.

nonplussed.definition: (verb) To perplex or bewilder someone; to confound or flummox; (adjective) Bewildered; unsure how to respond or act.

numinous.definition: (adjective) Of or relating to a numen (divinity); indicating the presence of a divinity.
numinous.examples: (adjective) His interest in numinous objects led him on a quest for the Holy Grail.

obdurate.definition: (verb) To harden; to obdure.; (adjective) Stubbornly persistent, generally in wrongdoing; refusing to reform or repent.

obeisance.definition: (noun) Demonstration of an obedient attitude, especially by bowing deeply; a deep bow which demonstrates such an attitude.

obfuscate.definition: (verb) To make dark; overshadow; (adjective) Obfuscated; darkened; obscured.
obfuscate.examples: (verb) Before leaving the scene, the murderer set a fire in order to obfuscate any evidence of their identity.

oblivious.definition: (adjective) (usually followed by to or of) Lacking awareness; unmindful; unaware, unconscious of.

obscure.definition: (verb) To render obscure; to darken; to make dim; to keep in the dark; to hide; to make less visible, intelligible, legible, glorious, beautiful, or illustrious.; (adjective) Dark, faint or indistinct.
obscure.examples: (adjective) an obscure passage or inscription;    The speaker made obscure references to little-known literary works.

obsequious.definition: (adjective) Obedient; compliant with someone else's orders or wishes.

obsolete.definition: (adjective) (of words, equipment, etc.) No longer in use; gone into disuse; disused or neglected (often by preference for something newer, which replaces the subject).
obsolete.examples: (adjective) It is speculated that, within a few years, the Internet's speedy delivery of news worldwide will make newspapers obsolete.

obstinate.definition: (adjective) Stubbornly adhering to an opinion, purpose, or course, usually with implied unreasonableness; persistent.

obstreperous.definition: (adjective) Attended by, or making, a loud and tumultuous noise; boisterous.

obviate.definition: (verb) To anticipate and prevent or bypass (something which would otherwise have been necessary or required).

occlude.definition: (verb) To obstruct, cover, or otherwise block (an opening, a portion of an image, etc.).

odious.definition: (adjective) Arousing or meriting strong dislike, aversion, or intense displeasure.
odious.examples: (adjective) Scrubbing the toilet is an odious task.

ominous.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to an omen or to omens; being or exhibiting an omen; significant.
ominous.examples: (adjective) California poll support for Jerry Brown's tax increases has ominous implications for U.S. taxpayers too Los Angeles Times Headline April 25, 2011

onerous.definition: (adjective) Imposing or constituting a physical, mental, or figurative load which can be borne only with effort; burdensome.

opaque.definition: (noun) An area of darkness; a place or region with no light.; (verb) To make, render (more) opaque.; (adjective) Neither reflecting nor emitting light.

opprobrium.definition: (noun) Disgrace arising from exceedingly shameful conduct; ignominy.

ossify.definition: (verb) To transform (or cause to transform) from a softer animal substance into bone; particularly the processes of growth in humans and animals.

oust.examples: (verb) The protesters became so noisy that they were finally ousted from the meeting.

outlandish.examples: (adjective) The rock star wore black with outlandish pink and green spiked hair.

outstrip.examples: (verb) We quickly outstripped the amateur runners.

overt.definition: (adjective) Open and not concealed or secret.

pacify.definition: (verb) To bring peace to (a place or situation), by ending war, fighting, violence, anger or agitation.

painstaking.definition: (noun) The application of careful and attentive effort.; (adjective) Carefully attentive to details; diligent in performing a process or procedure.

palpable.definition: (adjective) Capable of being touched, felt or handled; touchable, tangible.

panacea.definition: (noun) A remedy believed to cure all disease and prolong life that was originally sought by alchemists; a cure-all.
panacea.examples: (noun) A monorail will be a panacea for our traffic woes.

panache.definition: (noun) An ornamental plume on a helmet.

paradigmatic.definition: (noun) A writer of memoirs of religious persons, as examples of Christian excellence.; (adjective) Of or pertaining to a paradigm.

paragon.definition: (noun) A person of preeminent qualities, who acts as a pattern or model for others.; (verb) To compare; to parallel; to put in rivalry or emulation with.
paragon.examples: (noun) In the novel, Constanza is a paragon of virtue who would never compromise her reputation.

parochial.examples: (adjective) Some people in the United States have been accused of taking a parochial view, of not being interested in international matters.

parsimonious.definition: (adjective) Exhibiting parsimony; sparing in the expenditure of money; frugal to excess.

partial.definition: (noun) A partial derivative: a derivative with respect to one independent variable of a function in multiple variables while holding the other variables constant.; (verb) To take the partial regression coefficient.; (adjective) Existing as a part or portion; incomplete
partial.examples: (adjective) So far, I have only pieced together a partial account of the incident.

pastiche.definition: (noun) A work of art, drama, literature, music, or architecture that imitates the work of a previous artist.; (verb) To create or compose in a mixture of styles.
pastiche.examples: (noun) The house failed to attract a buyer because the decor was a pastiche of Bohemian and Scandinavian styles.

patent.definition: (noun) A declaration issued by a government agency declaring someone the inventor of a new invention and having the privilege of stopping others from making, using or selling the claimed invention; a letter patent.; (verb) To successfully register an invention with a government agency; to secure a letter patent.

patronize.definition: (verb) To act as a patron of; to defend, protect, or support.

peculiar.definition: (noun) That which is peculiar; a sole or exclusive property; a prerogative; a characteristic.; (adjective) Out of the ordinary; odd; strange; unusual.
peculiar.examples: (adjective) It would be rather peculiar to see a kangaroo hopping down a city street.

pedantic.definition: (adjective) Like a pedant, overly concerned with formal rules and trivial points of learning.

pedestrian.definition: (noun) A walker; one who walks or goes on foot, especially as opposed to one who uses a vehicle.; (adjective) Of or intended for those who are walking.

pellucid.definition: (adjective) Allowing the passage of light; transparent.

penchant.examples: (noun) He has a penchant for fine wine.

pensive.definition: (adjective) Having the appearance of deep, often melancholic, thinking.

penurious.examples: (adjective) The old man died a penurious wretch; eighty-thousand dollars in the mattress and as many holes in the roof.

perennial.definition: (noun) A perennial plant; a plant that is active throughout the year or survives for more than two growing seasons.; (adjective) Lasting or remaining active throughout the year, or all the time.

perfidy.definition: (noun) A state or act of violating faith or allegiance; violation of a promise or vow, or of trust

perfunctory.definition: (adjective) Done only to fulfil a duty, or in a careless or indifferent manner; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote.
perfunctory.examples: (adjective) He did a perfunctory job cleaning his dad's car, finishing quickly but leaving a few spots still dirty.

peripheral.definition: (noun) A peripheral device.; (adjective) On the periphery or boundary.

pernicious.definition: (adjective) Causing much harm in a subtle way.

perpetrate.definition: (verb) To be guilty of, or responsible for a crime etc; to commit.

perpetuate.definition: (verb) To make perpetual; to preserve from extinction or oblivion.; (adjective) Made perpetual; continued for an indefinite time.

perseverance.definition: (noun) Continuing in a course of action without regard to discouragement, opposition or previous failure.

perspicacious.definition: (adjective) Of acute discernment; having keen insight; mentally perceptive.

pertinacious.definition: (adjective) Holding tenaciously to an opinion or purpose.

pertinent.definition: (adjective) Important with regard to (a subject or matter); relevant

pervasive.definition: (adjective) Manifested throughout; pervading, permeating, penetrating or affecting everything.
pervasive.examples: (adjective) The medication had a pervasive effect on the patient's health.

petulant.examples: (adjective) Lack of sleep is causing Dave's recent petulant behavior.

philistine.definition: (noun) A person who is ignorant or uneducated; specifically, a person who lacks appreciation of or is antagonistic towards art or culture, and who has pedestrian tastes.; (adjective) Ignorant or uneducated; specifically, lacking appreciation for or antagonistic towards art or culture, and having pedestrian tastes.

phlegmatic.definition: (noun) One who has a phlegmatic disposition.; (adjective) Not easily excited to action or passion; calm; sluggish.

pious.definition: (adjective) Of or pertaining to piety, exhibiting piety, devout, godfearing.

placate.definition: (verb) To calm; to bring peace to; to influence someone who was furious to the point that they become content or at least no longer irate.

plaintive.examples: (adjective) a typically plaintive song from Radiohead

plastic.definition: (noun) A synthetic, solid, hydrocarbon-based polymer, whether thermoplastic or thermosetting.; (adjective) Capable of being moulded; malleable, flexible, pliant.

platitude.definition: (noun) An often-quoted saying that is supposed to be meaningful but has become unoriginal or hackneyed through overuse; a cliché.

pliant.definition: (adjective) Capable of plying or bending; readily yielding to force or pressure without breaking

plodding.definition: (verb) To walk or move slowly and heavily or laboriously (+ on, through, over).; (noun) Slow, laborious progress.; (adjective) Progressing slowly and laboriously.

ploy.examples: (noun) The free T-shirt is really a ploy to get you inside to see their sales pitch.

plucky.definition: (adjective) Having or showing pluck, courage or spirit in trying circumstances.

poignant.definition: (adjective) Of a weapon, etc.: sharp-pointed; keen.
poignant.examples: (adjective) A poignant reply will garner more credence than hours of blown smoke.

poise.definition: (noun) A state of balance, equilibrium or stability.; (verb) To hang in equilibrium; to be balanced or suspended; hence, to be in suspense or doubt.
poise.examples: (verb) I poised the crowbar in my hand, and waited.

polarize.definition: (verb) To cause to have a polarization.

polemical.definition: (noun) A diatribe or polemic.; (adjective) Related to argument or controversy; containing polemic, being polemic

polymath.definition: (noun) A person with extraordinarily broad and comprehensive knowledge.

pomposity.definition: (noun) The quality of being pompous; self-importance.
pomposity.examples: (noun) With their super-formal tone and heavy use of jargon, legal documents are renowned for their pomposity.

portend.definition: (verb) To serve as a warning or omen of.
portend.examples: (verb) Let it be known that the Rapture portends the End of Days.

precipitate.definition: (verb) To make something happen suddenly and quickly.; (adjective) Headlong; falling steeply or vertically.
precipitate.examples: (verb) it precipitated their success; (adjective) The king was too precipitate in declaring war.

preclude.definition: (verb) Remove the possibility of; rule out; prevent or exclude; to make impossible.
preclude.examples: (verb) It has been raining for days, but that doesn’t preclude the possibility that the skies will clear by this afternoon!

precocious.definition: (adjective) Characterized by exceptionally early development or maturity.
precocious.examples: (adjective) The precocious plant was already blooming flowers by day 4.

predicament.definition: (noun) A definite class, state or condition.

predilection.definition: (noun) Condition of favoring or liking; tendency towards; proclivity; predisposition.

premeditate.definition: (verb) To meditate, consider, or plan beforehand; to think about and revolve in the mind beforehand.

prescient.definition: (adjective) Exhibiting or possessing prescience: having knowledge of, or seemingly able to correctly predict, events before they take place.

presumptuous.definition: (adjective) Going beyond what is right, proper, or appropriate because of an excess of self-confidence or arrogance.

pretentious.examples: (adjective) Her dress was obviously more pretentious than comfortable.

prevaricate.definition: (verb) To deviate, transgress; to go astray (from).
prevaricate.examples: (verb) The people saw the politician prevaricate every day.

prime.definition: (noun) The first hour of daylight; the first canonical hour.; (adjective) First in importance, degree, or rank.
prime.examples: (noun) 3 is a prime.; (adjective) Our prime concern here is to keep the community safe.

pristine.definition: (adjective) Unspoiled; still with its original purity; uncorrupted or unsullied.

probity.definition: (noun) Integrity, especially of the quality of having strong moral principles; honesty and decency.

proclivity.definition: (noun) A predisposition or natural inclination, propensity, or a predilection; especially, a strong disposition or bent.
proclivity.examples: (noun) The child has a proclivity for exaggeration.

prodigal.definition: (noun) A prodigal person, a spendthrift.; (adjective) Wastefully extravagant.
prodigal.examples: (adjective) He found himself guilty of prodigal spending during the holidays.

prodigious.definition: (adjective) Very big in size or quantity; gigantic; colossal; huge.

proficient.definition: (noun) An expert.; (adjective) Good at something; skilled; fluent; practiced, especially in relation to a task or skill.
proficient.examples: (adjective) He was a proficient writer with an interest in human nature.

profligate.definition: (noun) An abandoned person; one openly and shamelessly vicious; a dissolute person.; (verb) To drive away; to overcome.; (adjective) Inclined to waste resources or behave extravagantly.

profound.definition: (noun) The deep; the sea; the ocean.; (verb) To cause to sink deeply; to cause to dive or penetrate far down.; (adjective) Descending far below the surface; opening or reaching to great depth; deep.

profundity.definition: (noun) The state of being profound or abstruse.

profuse.definition: (verb) To pour out; to give or spend liberally; to lavish; to squander.; (adjective) In great quantity or abundance; liberal or generous to the point of excess.
profuse.examples: (adjective) She grew profuse amounts of zucchini and pumpkins.

proliferate.definition: (verb) To increase in number or spread rapidly; to multiply.
proliferate.examples: (verb) The flowers proliferated rapidly all spring.

prolix.definition: (adjective) Tediously lengthy; dwelling on trivial details.

propagate.definition: (verb) (of animals or plants) To cause to continue or multiply by generation, or successive production

propensity.definition: (noun) An inclination, disposition, tendency, preference, or attraction.
propensity.examples: (noun) He has a propensity for lengthy discussions of certain favorite topics.

prophetic.definition: (adjective) Of, or relating to a prophecy or a prophet

propriety.definition: (noun) The particular character or essence of someone or something; individuality.

prosaic.definition: (adjective) Pertaining to or having the characteristics of prose.
prosaic.examples: (adjective) The tenor of Eliot's prosaic work differs greatly from that of his poetry.

provincial.definition: (noun) A person belonging to a province; one who is provincial.; (adjective) Of or pertaining to a province.

provocative.definition: (noun) (obsolescent) Something that provokes an appetite, especially a sexual appetite; an aphrodisiac.; (adjective) Serving or tending to elicit a strong, often negative sentiment in another person; exasperating.

prowess.definition: (noun) Skillfulness and manual ability; adroitness or dexterity.

proxy.definition: (noun) An agent or substitute authorized to act for another person.; (verb) To serve as a proxy for.; (adjective) Used as a proxy or acting as a proxy.

prudent.definition: (adjective) Sagacious in adapting means to ends; circumspect in action, or in determining any line of conduct; careful, discreet, sensible; — opposed to rash; directed by prudence or wise forethought; evincing prudence
prudent.examples: (adjective) His prudent career moves reliably brought him to the top

prurient.definition: (adjective) Uneasy with desire; itching; especially, having a lascivious anxiety or propensity; lustful.

pugnacious.definition: (adjective) Naturally aggressive or hostile; combative; belligerent; bellicose.

punctilious.definition: (adjective) Strictly attentive to detail; meticulous or fastidious, particularly to codes or conventions.
punctilious.examples: (adjective) With a punctilious slap of the gloves, the duel was now inevitable.

qualm.definition: (noun) A feeling of apprehension, doubt, fear etc.; (verb) To have a sickly feeling.
qualm.examples: (noun) This lawyer has no qualms about saving people who are on the wrong side of the law.

quandary.definition: (noun) A state of not knowing what to decide; a state of difficulty or perplexity; a state of uncertainty, hesitation or puzzlement.

quarantine.definition: (noun) The desert in which Christ fasted for 40 days according to the Bible.

quibble.definition: (noun) A pun.; (verb) To complain or argue in a trivial or petty manner.
quibble.examples: (noun) He harped on his quibble about how the dark red paint should be described as carmine rather than burgundy.; (verb) They are constantly quibbling over insignificant details.

quiescent.examples: (adjective) The bats were quiescent at that time of day, so we slowly entered the cave.

quirky.definition: (adjective) Given to quirks or idiosyncrasies; strange in a somewhat silly, awkward manner, potentially cute.

quixotic.definition: (adjective) Possessing or acting with the desire to do noble and romantic deeds, without thought of realism and practicality; exceedingly idealistic.

radical.definition: (noun) (historical: 19th-century Britain) A member of the most progressive wing of the Liberal Party; someone favouring social reform (but generally stopping short of socialism).; (adjective) Favoring fundamental change, or change at the root cause of a matter.

ramification.definition: (noun) A branching-out, the act or result of developing branches; specifically the divergence of the stem and limbs of a plant into smaller ones, or of similar developments in blood vessels, anatomical structures etc.

rampant.definition: (adjective) Rearing on both hind legs with the forelegs extended.
rampant.examples: (adjective) The Vienna riding school displays splendid rampant movement.

rational.definition: (noun) A rational number: a number that can be expressed as the quotient of two integers.; (adjective) Capable of reasoning.
rational.examples: (noun) The quotient of two rationals is again a rational.; (adjective) Man is a rational creature.

ravage.definition: (noun) Grievous damage or havoc.; (verb) To devastate or destroy something.
ravage.examples: (noun) the ravage of a lion; the ravages of fire or tempest; the ravages of an army, or of time

recant.definition: (verb) To withdraw or repudiate a statement or opinion formerly expressed, especially formally and publicly.
recant.examples: (verb) Convince me that I am wrong, and I will recant.

recluse.definition: (noun) A person who lives in self-imposed isolation or seclusion from the world, especially for religious purposes; a hermit; (verb) To shut; to seclude; (adjective) Sequestered; secluded, isolated

reconcile.definition: (verb) To restore a friendly relationship; to bring back to harmony.
reconcile.examples: (verb) to reconcile people who have quarrelled

recondite.definition: (noun) A recondite (hidden or obscure) person or thing.; (verb) To conceal, cover up, hide.; (adjective) Of areas of discussion or research: difficult, obscure.

recourse.definition: (noun) The act of seeking assistance or advice.; (verb) To return; to recur.

redoubtable.definition: (adjective) Eliciting respect or fear; imposing; awe-inspiring.
redoubtable.examples: (adjective) The redoubtable New York Times has been called the "newspaper of record" of the United States.

refine.definition: (verb) To purify; reduce to a fine, unmixed, or pure state; to free from impurities.

refute.definition: (verb) To prove (something) to be false or incorrect.

regress.definition: (noun) The act of passing back; passage back; return; retrogression.; (verb) To move backwards to an earlier stage; to devolve.
regress.examples: (verb) When we regress Y on X, we use the values of variable X to predict those of Y.

reiterate.definition: (noun) A tree with vertical branches alongside the main trunk and which continue to grow upwards.; (verb) To say or do (something) for a second time, such as for emphasis.; (adjective) Reiterated; repeated.

relegate.definition: (verb) Exile, banish, remove, or send away.

relent.definition: (noun) Stay; stop; delay.; (verb) To become less severe or intense; to become less hard, harsh, or cruel; to soften in temper; (adjective) Softhearted; yielding
relent.examples: (verb) He had planned to ground his son for a month, but relented and decided to give him a stern lecture instead.

relinquish.definition: (verb) To give up, abandon or retire from something. To trade away.

relish.definition: (noun) A pleasant taste; (verb) To taste or eat with pleasure, to like the flavor of

remote.definition: (noun) An element of broadcast programming originating away from the station's or show's control room.; (verb) To connect to a computer from a remote location.; (adjective) At a distance; disconnected.; (noun) A device used to operate an appliance (such as a television), vehicle or mechanical toy from a short distance away.
remote.examples: (adjective) A remote operator may control the vehicle with a wireless handset.; (noun) The bomb was detonated by remote control.

remuneration.definition: (noun) Something given in exchange for goods or services rendered.

render.definition: (noun) Stucco or plaster applied to walls (mostly to outside masonry walls).; (verb) (ditransitive) To cause to become.
render.examples: (noun) A low-resolution render might look blocky.; (verb) The shot rendered her immobile.

renege.definition: (verb) To break a promise or commitment; to go back on one's word.

renounce.definition: (noun) An act of renouncing.; (verb) To give up, resign, surrender, atsake.
renounce.examples: (verb) to renounce a title to land or to a throne

repercussion.definition: (noun) A consequence or ensuing result of some action.
repercussion.examples: (noun) You realize this little stunt of yours is going to have some pretty serious repercussions.

repertoire.definition: (noun) A list of dramas, operas, pieces, parts, etc., which a company or a person has rehearsed and is prepared to perform or display.
repertoire.examples: (noun) The conjurer expanded his repertoire with some new tricks.

replenish.definition: (verb) To refill; to renew; to supply again or to add a fresh quantity to.
replenish.examples: (verb) It's a popular product, and they have to replenish their stock of it frequently.

reproach.definition: (noun) A mild rebuke, or an implied criticism.; (verb) To criticize or rebuke (someone).

reprobate.definition: (noun) One rejected by God; a sinful person.; (adjective) Rejected; cast off as worthless.
reprobate.examples: (adjective) The reprobate criminal sneered at me.

repudiate.definition: (verb) To reject the truth or validity of; to deny.

repugnant.definition: (adjective) Offensive or repulsive; arousing disgust or aversion.

resilient.definition: (adjective) (of objects or substances) Returning quickly to original shape after force is applied; elastic.

resolute.definition: (noun) A determined person; one showing resolution.; (adjective) Firm, unyielding, determined.
resolute.examples: (adjective) He was resolute in his decision to stay.

restive.definition: (adjective) Impatient under delay, duress, or control.

retaliate.definition: (verb) To do something harmful or negative to get revenge for some harm; to fight back or respond in kind to an injury or affront.
retaliate.examples: (verb) John insulted Peter to retaliate for Peter's acid remark earlier.

reticent.definition: (adjective) Keeping one's thoughts and opinions to oneself; reserved or restrained.

retiring.definition: (verb) To stop working on a permanent basis, usually because of old age or illness.; (verb) To fit (a vehicle) with new tires.; (noun) Retirement; (adjective) Introverted, liking privacy and seclusion.
retiring.examples: (verb) Having made a large fortune, he retired.; (adjective) I don't really know him well, since he's so shy and retiring.

rhapsody.definition: (noun) An ancient Greek epic poem (or part of one) suitable for uninterrupted recitation.

rhetoric.definition: (noun) The art of using language, especially public speaking, as a means to persuade.; (adjective) Part of or similar to rhetoric, the use of language as a means to persuade.
rhetoric.examples: (noun) It’s only so much rhetoric.; (adjective) A rhetorical question is one used merely to make a point, with no response expected.

rigor.definition: (noun) Short for rigor mortis.; (noun) Severity or strictness.

robust.examples: (adjective) A robust wall was put up.

rudimentary.definition: (noun) (usually in the plural) One of the rudimentary mammae of boars.; (adjective) Of or relating to one or more rudiments.
rudimentary.examples: (adjective) I have only a rudimentary grasp of chemistry.

ruminate.definition: (verb) To chew cud. (Said of ruminants.) Involves regurgitating partially digested food from the rumen.; (adjective) Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filled with softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North American papaw.
ruminate.examples: (verb) A camel will ruminate just as a cow will.; (adjective) a ruminate endosperm

sadistic.definition: (adjective) Delighting in or feeling pleasure from the pain or humiliation of others.

sagacious.definition: (adjective) Having or showing keen discernment, sound judgment, and farsightedness; mentally shrewd.

salubrious.definition: (adjective) Promoting health or well-being; wholesome, especially as related to air.

salutary.definition: (adjective) Effecting or designed to effect an improvement; remedial: salutary advice.

sanctimonious.definition: (adjective) Making a show of being morally better than others, especially hypocritically pious.

sanction.definition: (noun) An approval, by an authority, generally one that makes something valid.; (verb) To ratify; to make valid.
sanction.examples: (noun) The whalers had been operating in the contested waters off the island with sanction from the Japanese government.

sanguine.definition: (noun) Blood colour; red.; (verb) To stain with blood; to impart the colour of blood to; to ensanguine.; (adjective) Having the colour of blood; blood red.

satirical.definition: (adjective) Of, pertaining to or connected with satire
satirical.examples: (adjective) Spitting Image was a famous satirical television program.

scant.examples: (adjective) After his previous escapades, Mary had scant reason to believe John.

scathing.definition: (verb) To injure or harm.; (adjective) Harshly or bitterly critical; vitriolic

schism.definition: (noun) A split or separation within a group or organization, typically caused by discord.
schism.examples: (noun) The schism between Sunnis and Shias happened quite early in Islamic history.

scintillating.definition: (verb) To give off sparks; to shine as if emanating sparks; to twinkle or glow.; (adjective) That scintillates with brief flashes of light; sparkling.

scorn.definition: (noun) Contempt or disdain.; (verb) To feel or display contempt or disdain for something or somebody; to despise.

scrupulous.examples: (adjective) He is scrupulous in his finances.

sedulous.definition: (adjective) Of a person: diligent in application or pursuit; constant and persevering in business or in endeavours to effect a goal; steadily industrious.

sentimental.definition: (adjective) Characterized by sentiment, sentimentality or excess emotion.

serendipitous.definition: (adjective) By serendipity; by unexpected good fortune
serendipitous.examples: (adjective) The weather was serendipitous for our vacation.

serene.definition: (noun) Serenity; clearness; calmness.; (verb) To make serene.; (adjective) Peaceful, calm, unruffled.
serene.examples: (adjective) She looked at her students with joviality and a serene mentality.

sever.examples: (verb) After he graduated, he severed all links to his family.

sham.definition: (noun) A fake; an imitation that purports to be genuine.; (verb) To deceive, cheat, lie.; (adjective) Intended to deceive; false.
sham.examples: (noun) The time-share deal was a sham.; (adjective) It was only a sham wedding: they didn't care much for one another, but wanted their parents to stop hassling them.

shirk.definition: (noun) One who shirks, who avoids a duty or responsibility.; (verb) To avoid, especially a duty, responsibility, etc.; to stay away from.
shirk.examples: (verb) If you have a job, don't shirk from it by staying off work.

shrill.definition: (noun) A shrill sound.; (verb) To make a shrill noise.; (adjective) High-pitched and piercing.
shrill.examples: (adjective) The woods rang with shrill cries of the birds.

sinecure.definition: (noun) A position that requires no work but still gives an ample payment; a cushy job.; (verb) To put or place in a sinecure.

sinuous.definition: (adjective) Having curves in alternate directions; meandering.
sinuous.examples: (adjective) We followed every bend of the sinuous river.

skirt.definition: (noun) An article of clothing, usually worn by women and girls, that hangs from the waist and covers the lower part of the body.; (verb) To be on or form the border of.
skirt.examples: (verb) The plain was skirted by rows of trees.

skittish.examples: (adjective) The cat likes people he knows, but he is skittish around strangers.

slander.definition: (noun) A false or unsupported, malicious statement (spoken, not written), especially one which is injurious to a person's reputation; the making of such a statement.; (verb) To utter a slanderous statement about; baselessly speak ill of.

slight.definition: (noun) The act of slighting; a deliberate act of neglect or discourtesy.; (verb) To treat as unimportant or not worthy of attention; to make light of.; (adjective) Small

slovenly.definition: (adjective) Having an untidy appearance; unkempt.; (adverb) In a slovenly manner.

sluggish.definition: (adjective) Habitually idle and lazy; slothful; dull; inactive

soliloquy.definition: (noun) The act of a character speaking to themselves so as to reveal their thoughts to the audience.; (verb) (very rare) To issue a soliloquy.
soliloquy.examples: (noun) At the end of the second act the main villain gave a soliloquy detailing his plans to attack the protagonist.

sophisticated.definition: (verb) To make less natural or innocent.; (adjective) Having obtained worldly experience, and lacking naiveté; cosmopolitan.

soporific.definition: (noun) Something inducing sleep, especially a drug.; (adjective) (pharmaceutical effect) Tending to induce sleep.
soporific.examples: (noun) The doctor prescribed a soporific to help the patient sleep.; (adjective) The professor delivered a soporific lecture.

sound.definition: (adjective) Healthy.; (adverb) Soundly.; (interjection) Yes; used to show agreement or understanding, generally without much enthusiasm.

sparse.definition: (verb) To scatter; to disperse.; (adjective) Having widely spaced intervals.
sparse.examples: (adjective) a sparse array, index, or matrix

spartan.examples: (adjective) I went on the retreat to the monastery, thinking I would be sleeping in a spartan cell, only to discover a simple but comfortable bedroom.

specious.definition: (adjective) Seemingly well-reasoned, plausible or true, but actually fallacious.
specious.examples: (adjective) This idea that we must see through what we have started is specious, however good it may sound.

spendthrift.definition: (noun) Someone who spends money improvidently or wastefully.; (adjective) Improvident, profligate, or wasteful.

sporadic.definition: (adjective) (of diseases) occurring in isolated instances; not epidemic.

spurious.examples: (adjective) His argument was spurious and had no validity.

spurn.definition: (noun) An act of spurning; a scornful rejection.; (verb) To reject disdainfully; contemn; scorn.

squander.definition: (verb) To waste, lavish, splurge; to spend lavishly or profusely; to dissipate.

stalwart.definition: (noun) One who has a strong build.; (adjective) Firmly or solidly built.

stanch.definition: (noun) That which stanches or checks a flow.; (verb) To stop the flow of.; (adjective) Strong and tight; sound; firm.
stanch.examples: (verb) A small amount of cotton can be stuffed into the nose to stanch the flow of blood if necessary.; (adjective) a stanch ship

stern.definition: (adjective) Having a hardness and severity of nature or manner.

stigmatize.definition: (verb) To characterize as disgraceful or ignominious; to mark with a stigma or stigmata.

stint.definition: (noun) A period of time spent doing or being something; a spell.; (verb) To stop (an action); cease, desist.
stint.examples: (noun) He had a stint in jail.; (verb) The next party you throw, don't stint on the beer.

stoic.definition: (noun) Proponent of stoicism, a school of thought, from in 300 B.C.E. up to about the time of Marcus Aurelius, who holds that by cultivating an understanding of the logos, or natural law, one can be free of suffering.; (adjective) Of or relating to the Stoics or their ideas.

stolid.definition: (adjective) Having or revealing little emotion or sensibility; dully or heavily stupid.

stringent.definition: (adjective) Strict; binding strongly; making strict requirements; restrictive; rigid; severe
stringent.examples: (adjective) They have stringent quality requirements outlining what is acceptable.

subjective.definition: (adjective) Formed, as in opinions, based upon a person's feelings or intuition, not upon observation or reasoning; coming more from within the observer than from observations of the external environment.

subordinate.definition: (noun) One who is subordinate.; (verb) To make subservient.; (adjective) Placed in a lower class, rank, or position.
subordinate.examples: (adjective) In the sentence “The barbecue finished before John arrived”, the subordinate clause “before John arrived” specifies the time of the main clause, “The barbecue finished”.

subside.definition: (verb) To sink or fall to the bottom; to settle, as lees.

substantiate.definition: (verb) To verify something by supplying evidence; to authenticate or corroborate

subsume.definition: (verb) To place (any one cognition) under another as belonging to it; to include or contain something else.

subtle.definition: (adjective) Hard to grasp; not obvious or easily understood; barely noticeable.
subtle.examples: (adjective) The difference is subtle, but you can hear it if you listen carefully.

subvert.definition: (verb) To overturn from the foundation; to overthrow; to ruin utterly.
subvert.examples: (verb) A dictator stays in power only as long as he manages to subvert the will of his people.

superficial.definition: (noun) (chiefly in plural) A surface detail.; (adjective) Of or pertaining to the surface.
superficial.examples: (noun) He always concentrates on the superficials and fails to see the real issue.

superfluous.definition: (adjective) In excess of what is required or sufficient.
superfluous.examples: (adjective) With a full rain suit, carrying an umbrella may be superfluous.

supersede.definition: (noun) An updated newsgroup post that supersedes an earlier version.; (verb) To take the place of.
supersede.examples: (noun) Rogue cancels and supersedes are being issued on a large scale against posters.; (verb) Those older products have been superseded by our new range.

supplant.definition: (verb) To take the place of; to replace, to supersede.
supplant.examples: (verb) Will online dictionaries ever supplant paper dictionaries?

supple.definition: (verb) To make or become supple.; (adjective) Pliant, flexible, easy to bend

supplicate.definition: (verb) To humble oneself before (another) in making a request; to beg or beseech.
supplicate.examples: (verb) to supplicate blessings on Christian efforts to spread the gospel

surfeit.definition: (noun) An excessive amount of something.; (verb) To fill (something) to excess.
surfeit.examples: (noun) A surfeit of wheat is driving down the price.; (verb) She surfeited her children on sweets.

surreptitious.definition: (adjective) Stealthy, furtive, well hidden, covert (especially movements).

suspect.definition: (noun) A person who is suspected of something, in particular of committing a crime.; (verb) To imagine or suppose (something) to be true, or to exist, without proof.; (adjective) Viewed with suspicion; suspected.
suspect.examples: (verb) to suspect the presence of disease

swindle.definition: (noun) An instance of swindling.; (verb) To defraud.
swindle.examples: (verb) The two men swindled the company out of $160,000.

synoptic.definition: (adjective) Of or relating to a synopsis.

tacit.definition: (adjective) Expressed in silence; implied, but not made explicit; silent.
tacit.examples: (adjective) tacit consent : consent by silence, or by not raising an objection

taciturn.definition: (adjective) Silent; temperamentally untalkative; disinclined to speak.
taciturn.examples: (adjective) The two sisters could hardly have been more different, one so boisterous and expressive, the other so taciturn and calm.

tact.definition: (noun) The sense of touch; feeling.; (verb) To use a tact (a kind of verbal operant; see noun sense).; (noun) A maneuver, or action calculated to achieve some end.
tact.examples: (noun) By the use of tact, she was able to calm her jealous husband.

tangential.definition: (adjective) Referring to a tangent, moving at a tangent to something.
tangential.examples: (adjective) That subject is tangential to our discussion, and we cannot let it distract us.

tangible.definition: (noun) A physical object, something that can be touched.; (adjective) Touchable; able to be touched or felt; perceptible by the sense of touch
tangible.examples: (noun) Yes, but what are the tangibles?

tantalizing.definition: (verb) To tease (someone) by offering something desirable but keeping it out of reach; (noun) Teasing temptation; (adjective) Teasing; tempting, especially that which is beyond reach.

tantamount.definition: (noun) Something which has the same value or amount (as something else). (attributive use passing into adjective, below); (verb) To amount to as much; to be equivalent.; (adjective) Equivalent in meaning or effect; amounting to the same thing in practical terms, even if being technically distinct.
tantamount.examples: (adjective) In this view, disagreement and treason are tantamount.

tarnish.definition: (noun) Oxidation or discoloration, especially of a decorative metal exposed to air.; (verb) To oxidize or discolor due to oxidation.
tarnish.examples: (verb) Careful storage of silver will prevent it from tarnishing.

temper.definition: (noun) A tendency to be in a certain type of mood; a habitual way of thinking, behaving or reacting.; (verb) To moderate or control.
temper.examples: (noun) to have a good, bad, or calm temper; (verb) Temper your language around children.

tempestuous.definition: (adjective) Of, or resembling a tempest; stormy, tumultuous.

temporal.definition: (noun) (chiefly in the plural) Anything temporal or secular; a temporality.; (adjective) (also grammar) Of or relating to time.

tenable.definition: (adjective) (of a theory, argument, etc.) capable of being maintained or justified; well-founded
tenable.examples: (adjective) Back in the 1800s, many did not consider Darwin's theory of evolution to be tenable at all.

tendentious.definition: (adjective) Having a tendency; written or spoken with a partisan, biased or prejudiced purpose, especially a controversial one.
tendentious.examples: (adjective) As a supporter of the cause, his reports were tendentious in the extreme.

tentative.definition: (noun) A trial; an experiment; an attempt.; (adjective) Of or pertaining to a trial or trials; essaying; experimental.

tenuous.examples: (adjective) Far from being amicable, the numbers seemed to turn their backs on each other, and I couldn't find a pair with even the most tenuous connection.

tepid.examples: (adjective) I'm drinking a cup of tepid water.

terse.definition: (adjective) (by extension) Of speech or style: brief, concise, to the point.

thorough.definition: (noun) A furrow between two ridges, to drain off the surface water.; (adjective) Painstaking and careful not to miss or omit any detail.; (preposition) Through.
thorough.examples: (adjective) He is the most thorough worker I have ever seen.

tirade.definition: (noun) A long, angry or violent speech; a diatribe.; (verb) To make a long, angry or violent speech, a tirade.

torpor.definition: (noun) A state of being inactive or stuporous.

tout.definition: (noun) Someone advertising for customers in an aggressive way.; (verb) To flaunt, to publicize/publicise; to boast or brag; to promote.
tout.examples: (noun) Be careful of the ticket touts outside the arena, they are famed for selling counterfeits.; (verb) Mary has been touted as a potential succesor to the current COE.

tractable.definition: (adjective) (of people) Capable of being easily led, taught, or managed.

tranquil.definition: (adjective) Free from emotional or mental disturbance.

transcend.definition: (verb) To pass beyond the limits of something.
transcend.examples: (verb) lights in the heavens transcending the region of the clouds

transgression.definition: (noun) A violation of a law, duty or commandment.

transient.definition: (noun) Something which is transient.; (adjective) Passing or disappearing with time; transitory.

transitory.definition: (adjective) Lasting only a short time; temporary.

treatise.definition: (noun) A formal, usually lengthy, systematic discourse on some subject.

trenchant.definition: (adjective) Fitted to trench or cut; gutting; sharp.

trifling.definition: (noun) The act of one who trifles; frivolous behaviour.; (adjective) Trivial, or of little importance.

trivial.definition: (noun) Any of the three liberal arts forming the trivium.; (adjective) Ignorable; of little significance or value.

truculent.examples: (adjective) The truculent soldiers gave us a steely-eyed stare.

turbid.definition: (adjective) (of a liquid) Having the lees or sediment disturbed; not clear.

turbulent.definition: (adjective) Violently disturbed or agitated; tempestuous, tumultuous
turbulent.examples: (adjective) It is dangerous to sail in turbulent seas.

turgid.definition: (adjective) Distended beyond the natural state by some internal agent, especially fluid, or expansive force.

turpitude.definition: (noun) Inherent baseness, depravity or wickedness; corruptness and evilness.

ubiquitous.examples: (adjective) To Hindus, Jews, Christians, and Muslims, God is ubiquitous.

ulterior.definition: (adjective) Situated beyond, or on the farther side.

umbrage.definition: (noun) A feeling of anger or annoyance caused by something offensive.; (verb) To displease or cause offense.

unalloyed.definition: (adjective) (of metal) Not alloyed; not in mixture with other metals; pure.

undercut.definition: (noun) A cut made in the lower part of something; the material so removed.; (verb) To sell (something) at a lower price, or to work for lower wages, than a competitor.; (adjective) Produced by undercutting.

undermine.definition: (verb) To dig underneath (something), to make a passage for destructive or military purposes; to sap.
undermine.examples: (verb) The war efforts were undermined by the constant bickering between the allies.

underscore.definition: (noun) An underline; a line drawn or printed beneath text; the character _.; (verb) To underline; to mark a line beneath text.
underscore.examples: (verb) I wish to underscore the importance of proper formatting.

understated.definition: (verb) To state (something) with less completeness than needed; to minimise or downplay.; (adjective) Restrained and unpretentious.

universal.definition: (noun) A characteristic or property that particular things have in common.; (adjective) Of or pertaining to the universe.

unprecedented.definition: (adjective) Never before seen, done, or experienced; without precedent.

unseemly.definition: (adjective) Inconsistent with established standards of good form or taste.; (adverb) In an unseemly manner.
unseemly.examples: (adjective) He was drunk and made some very unseemly comments.

upbraid.definition: (noun) The act of reproaching; scorn; disdain.; (verb) To criticize severely.

urbane.definition: (adjective) (of a man) Courteous, polite, refined, and suave.

utilitarian.definition: (noun) Someone who practices or advocates utilitarianism.; (adjective) Of or relating to utility

utterly.definition: (adverb) Completely, entirely, to the fullest extent

vacillate.definition: (verb) To sway unsteadily from one side to the other; oscillate.

vapid.definition: (adjective) Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging.

venerate.definition: (verb) To treat with great respect and deference.

veracity.definition: (noun) (of a person) The quality of speaking or stating the truth; truthfulness.

verbose.definition: (adjective) Abounding in words, containing more words than necessary; long-winded.

verisimilitude.definition: (noun) The property of seeming true, of resembling reality; resemblance to reality, realism.

versatile.definition: (adjective) Capable of doing many things competently.
versatile.examples: (adjective) 2004, "queenchaser1158", Horny Versatile TV/TS Wanted in Phoenix (on newsgroup alt.personals.gay)

verve.definition: (noun) Excitement of imagination such as that which animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing

vexation.definition: (noun) The act of annoying, vexing, or irritating.

viable.definition: (noun) An organism that is able to live and develop.; (adjective) Able to live on its own (as for a newborn).

vigilant.definition: (adjective) Watchful, especially for danger or disorder; alert; wary
vigilant.examples: (adjective) Be vigilant for signs of disease in your garden.

virulent.definition: (adjective) (of a disease or disease-causing agent) Highly infectious, malignant or deadly.
virulent.examples: (adjective) The politicians were virulent in their hatred of the president.

visionary.definition: (noun) Someone who has visions; a seer; (adjective) Having vision or foresight

vitality.definition: (noun) The capacity to live and develop.

vitiate.definition: (verb) To spoil, make faulty; to reduce the value, quality, or effectiveness of something

vivacious.definition: (adjective) Lively and animated; full of life and energy.

vociferous.definition: (adjective) Making or characterized by a noisy outcry; clamorous.

volatile.definition: (noun) A chemical or compound that changes into a gas easily.; (adjective) Evaporating or vaporizing readily under normal conditions.

voluble.definition: (adjective) (of a person or a manner of speaking) Fluent or having a ready flow of speech; garrulous or loquacious; tonguey.

wane.definition: (noun) A gradual diminution in power, value, intensity etc.; (verb) To progressively lose its splendor, value, ardor, power, intensity etc.; to decline.

wary.definition: (adjective) Cautious of danger; carefully watching and guarding against deception, trickery, and dangers; suspiciously prudent

wayward.definition: (adjective) Given to wilful, perverse deviation from the expected norm; tending to stray

weary.definition: (verb) To make or to become weary.; (adjective) Having the strength exhausted by toil or exertion; tired; fatigued.
weary.examples: (adjective) A weary traveller knocked at the door.

wheedle.definition: (noun) A coaxing person.; (verb) To cajole or attempt to persuade by flattery.
wheedle.examples: (verb) I'd like one of those, too, if you can wheedle him into telling you where he got it.

wily.examples: (adjective) Horatio's new girlfriend is a wily coquette and poor Horatio is too smitten to see it.

woeful.definition: (adjective) Full of woe; sorrowful; distressed with grief or calamity.

xenophobic.definition: (noun) A xenophobe.; (adjective) Exhibiting or characterised by xenophobia, a fear or hatred of strangers or foreigners
xenophobic.examples: (adjective) "Residents of Plettenberg Bay this week launched violent xenophobic attacks on foreign Africans living in informal settlements, beating them and ransacking their houses" Weekend Argus May 13/14 2006.

yield.definition: (verb) To pay, give in payment; repay, recompense; reward; requite.
yield.examples: (verb) Yield the right of way to pedestrians.

zealous.definition: (adjective) Full of zeal; ardent, fervent; exhibiting enthusiasm or strong passion.

zenith.definition: (noun) The point in the sky vertically above a given position or observer; the point in the celestial sphere opposite the nadir.
zenith.examples: (noun) Winning the continental championship was the zenith of my career.
